conversation:
Shadowheart: You made it. Come here - sit with me.
~She smiles, pours a cup, and offers the player a cup of wine hands it to the player
NodeContext: Shadowheart is sitting with a bottle in her hand.
Player: What do you have in mind? Besides the bottle, that is.
Shadowheart: Well, to begin, I think a toast is in order. Any suggestions?
Player: To survival.
Shadowheart: Very practical. We could've toasted to that every night so far. Here's to many more. Survival. Now tell me something about yourself. And no tadpoles, dragons, marauding goblins, or anything like that. Something about you.
NodeContext: Shadowheart is sitting down.
Player: You first.
Shadowheart: Oh, no. I provided the refreshments. You can supply the entertainment. And no tadpoles, dragons, marauding goblins, or anything like that. Something about you.
NodeContext: Shadowheart is sitting down.
Player: Lower your guard and describe the desolate beauty of your home: Crèche K'liir.
Shadowheart: Merciless, but beautiful in its own way... Sounds familiar. Don't stop now. Not just as things are getting interesting...
Player: Your turn - I insist. A little give and take is only fair.
Shadowheart: Don't laugh... but I'm not quite sure I have anything to share. When you worship Shar, secrecy is everything. We'll sacrifice our own memories when ordered to. A lot of the little things... they're lost to me right now.
Player: Drinking wine won't help that.
Shadowheart: On the contrary. It helps me create all new memories.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene transitions as SH and the player continue to bond and talk the night away. Things pick back up just before morning.
Shadowheart: Nearly light. The others will be awake soon...
~Shadowheart lifts the wine bottle and gives it one last shake over her mouth, it's empty, she sets it back down
NodeContext: Shadowheart is sitting down.
Player: Look into her eyes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~The player looks over at Shadowheart, who looks back when she realizes she's being observed
Shadowheart: What?
Player: You're beautiful.
Shadowheart: I know. But you're sweet to notice. Thank you for last night.
Player: I hope there'll be more to come.
Shadowheart: Me too.
Player: We should do this again sometime.

Shadowheart: You made it. Come here - sit with me.
~She smiles, pours a cup, and offers the player a cup of wine hands it to the player
NodeContext: Shadowheart is sitting with a bottle in her hand.
Player: What do you have in mind? Besides the bottle, that is.
Shadowheart: Well, to begin, I think a toast is in order. Any suggestions?
Player: To victory.
Shadowheart: Dominant, self-centred, savouring another's loss... ...I like it. To victory.
NodeContext: A toast, Shadowheart is sitting down.
Shadowheart: Now tell me something about yourself. And no tadpoles, dragons, marauding goblins, or anything like that. Something about you.
NodeContext: Shadowheart is sitting down.
Player: Speak of an uncertain youth, neither fully at home with humans or orcs. A youth that forged resilience, self-reliance.
Shadowheart: I can sympathise, truly. Don't stop now. Not just as things are getting interesting...
Player: We should head back. We might be missed.
Shadowheart: I'm sure they'd last another while without us. But if you insist...
Player: I suppose there's not that much of a rush.
Shadowheart: Nothing worthwhile should be rushed anyway. There's still plenty of wine and the whole night ahead of us.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene transitions as SH and the player continue to bond and talk the night away. Things pick back up just before morning.
Shadowheart: Nearly light. The others will be awake soon...
~Shadowheart lifts the wine bottle and gives it one last shake over her mouth, it's empty, she sets it back down
NodeContext: Shadowheart is sitting down.
Player: The others can wait. I don't want this to end just yet.
Shadowheart: Another moment won't kill them, I suppose... Well, it might, but let's take that risk. Thank you for last night.
Player: I hope there'll be more to come.
Shadowheart: Me too.
Player: We should do this again sometime.

Shadowheart: The leader of the pack comes to chat. What's on your mind? You must be pleased to have a clear path forward. Finally, some good fortune. Come morning, we know what to do. I can't wait to get this thing out of my head.
Player: So what will come next for you, once this is all over?
Shadowheart: Head to Baldur's Gate. Someone's waiting for me.
Player: Oh yes? Who?
Shadowheart: Let a girl have some secrets. Was there anything else?
Player: You know, this could be our last night together.
Shadowheart: I hope not. I'd miss our little conversations... wouldn't you miss them as well?
Player: I have enjoyed your company, yes.
Shadowheart: I'm glad. Hopefully we can eke out some more time together, before all's done and dusted... I can't wait to get this thing out of my head.

Shadowheart: What a glorious celebration. Hip-deep in gore. And you're carousing with Minthara. Careful that she doesn't take a piece of you as a souvenir. Not that I'm judging. I have this. The goblins stole good wine. It goes straight to the head.
Player: Push into her thoughts.
Narrator: *Shadowheart's mind is drenched in drink and confusion. She's killed before - enjoyed it, even.* *But now an ill, twisting feeling lingers in her gut. One that has nothing to do with the wine.*
Shadowheart: The goblins stole good wine. It goes straight to the head.

NodeContext: Shadowheart is sitting down.
Player: Share a little memory from growing up in Baldur's Gate.
Shadowheart: Seems like you truly know the city. I never got to explore it to my liking. Don't stop now. Not just as things are getting interesting...
Player: Your turn - I insist. A little give and take is only fair.
Shadowheart: Oh? And what else do you find to be fair?
Player: Honestly? You.
Shadowheart: You don't waste time, do you? There's still plenty of wine and the whole night ahead of us.

NodeContext: Shadowheart is sitting down.
Player: Look into her eyes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~The player looks over at Shadowheart, who looks back when she realizes she's being observed
Shadowheart: What?
Player: Just checking for signs of ceremorphosis.
Shadowheart: Oh, I'm perfectly fine, but the mood is well and truly dead. Anyway. Thank you for tonight. Thank you for last night.
Player: My pleasure.
Shadowheart: It was just what I needed.
Narrator: *She trails off. You read an invitation in her eyes.*
Player: Let the moment pass.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Hello, sweetness.
Player: What happened to Mayrina? Did you do something to her?
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: I don't like busybodies.
Player: You have an interesting home.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Beautiful, isn't it? It's my little refuge for the lost and hopeless. People in dire need travel from all over Faerûn to see little ol' me. And I do my damndest to help them. And you, petal - well, you need a lot of help. That wriggler swimming in your brain juice is a bit of an inconvenience, isn't it?
Player: Something isn't right. That woman - why is she with you?
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Busybodies are not appreciated around here.
Astarion: Let's not make trouble for some stranger. We have our own problems.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: I'll talk about your wriggler - and that's it. Last warning.
Player: Fine. Can you remove the parasite?
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Quicker than you can say 'Yes, Auntie.' What do you say? Want me to take care of the little bugger?
Player: Yes. Get this damn parasite out of me.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: My - I do like them eager. But know that I don't work for free. I expect payment up front... One of your pretty little peepers. I'll pluck it from your head, kiss it for luck, then back in it goes. Won't take but a moment. That is my price. Nothing more, nothing less.
Player: You have a deal.

Shadowheart: You're here. Just like it told me. And with a gith - I should have figured.
Narrator: *Your mind rushes into hers - a storm of desperation, confusion and a will other than her own.*

Shadowheart: It took me so long to find you.
Player: You're infected, same as me. How did you get here?
Shadowheart: Quiet! I can't... concentrate with all these voices! Just listen. The whispering won't let me sleep. It keeps pushing me - to you. Even when I'm awake, I dream. There's blood, there's so much blood. I can't sleep. The whispering won't let me. It keeps pushing me - to you.
NodeContext: On, " to you" SH's hand drifts toward a knife tucked into her belt at the small her back
Gale: Careful! She's about to lash out.
Narrator: *There is a knife hidden in her belt. Her fingers twitch towards the hilt, ready to draw the blade.*
Player: Keep your hands away from that blade.
Shadowheart: I keep thinking about the knife going deep. It's the only thing they want me to see. And I think they'll stop once I deal with you.
Player: Don't do anything rash. There has to be an explanation for this.
Shadowheart: I don't want explanations. I want sleep. The whispering's already quieter here. Once you're dead, it'll be gone entirely.
Player: Threaten me again, and it'll be the last thing you do.
Shadowheart: What else do I do? My head is splitting open. I can't leave. I can't!
Player: Attack her.

Shadowheart: I don't know what you mean.
Player: That diary we found in Moonhaven - it meant something to you, I know it.
Shadowheart: It's nothing. Really.
Player: No more secrets. Tell me. Tell me what you're hiding. I can make you talk if I have to.
Shadowheart: Fine, I'll tell you, so long as it spares me your ham-fisted threats. You're not going to let this go, are you? You might wish you had... I worship Shar, the Mistress of the Night. It is my holy mission to oppose Selûne, her teachings and her followers. Ngh... it hurts... Now that you have the truth, please don't make a big fuss about it.
Player: I don't care who you worship. We have bigger problems.
Shadowheart: Then it's your own fault for not asking.
Player: Now that the truth's out, tell me more.
Shadowheart: All right. As I said, Shar is my patron, my mistress. Goddess of darkness and loss. I assume you've heard of her?
Player: She doesn't sound very appealing, going by her titles.
Shadowheart: The night brings comfort. Through loss, we find acceptance. In the arms of the Dark Mother we find peace.
Player: I don't quite understand.
Shadowheart: Most fear the dark, like children, because in darkness they see their fears reflected. But Shar teaches us to step beyond fear. Beyond loss. In darkness we do not hide - we act. Pain. Hope. The promise of better days. All of these are heavy cloaks that bend our backs and burden our hearts. We shed those cloaks. Before Shar we stand gloriously naked, beyond the vanities of mortals.
Player: How exactly do Shar worshippers turn people to their goddess?
Shadowheart: We tear down the lies the world is drunk on: the institutions they trust, the so-called gods they worship. The lives they cling to. We destroy false idols, topple corrupt organisations, fight heretics wherever they're found. There's often suffering - death even. Many people break before they embrace Shar's truths.
Player: It sounds evil.

Shadowheart: Most fear the dark, like children, because in darkness they see their fears reflected. But Shar teaches us to step beyond fear. Beyond loss. In darkness we do not hide - we act. Pain. Hope. The promise of better days. All of these are heavy cloaks that bend our backs and burden our hearts. We shed those cloaks. Before Shar we stand gloriously naked, beyond the vanities of mortals.

Shadowheart: There's comfort, yes. But often there has to be pain beforehand... We tear down the lies the world is drunk on: the institutions they trust, the so-called gods they worship. Many people break before they embrace Shar's truths.

Shadowheart: Hrmph. Only if you lack foresight and imagination. Most fear the dark, like children, because in darkness they see their fears reflected. But Shar teaches us to step beyond fear. Beyond loss. In darkness we do not hide - we act. Pain. Hope. The promise of better days. All of these are heavy cloaks that bend our backs and burden our hearts. We shed those cloaks. Before Shar we stand gloriously naked, beyond the vanities of mortals.
Player: Sounds... daunting. I don't think it's for me.
Shadowheart: Give it time - and thought. We tear down the lies the world is drunk on: the institutions they trust, the so-called gods they worship. The lives they cling to. We destroy false idols, topple corrupt organisations, fight heretics wherever they're found. There's often suffering - death even. Many people break before they embrace Shar's truths.
Player: It sounds evil.

Shadowheart: I hope that's true, but I'm not so sure. She has a far reach, and a long memory. I have an idea. Something I've wanted to do for a while. Something that might help me put her in the past... but I'll need your help. I have an idea, but I'll need your help.
Player: What do I need to do?

Player: There's no time for this.
Shadowheart: I had thought you would want to make time for me... I suppose I was wrong. Rest well then.

Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create. General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall. You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: As you mention serving Ketheric, he sent you to find a relic, no?
Balthazar: General Thorm to you. But yes, recovering the relic is the crux of it. He commands, and I, his humble servant, fulfil that command. While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: What are the properties of this relic, magical or otherwise? So I can be of better assistance, of course. I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?
Balthazar: Fine, if it'll spare me your bleating. The relic lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work... Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: For jobs like this it's good form to provide your operatives some extra resources.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell... ...Hmm. Misplaced, it seems. You will be capable enough without it.
Player: This sounds like your problem, not mine. Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do. I'll see what I can do.

Player: How did you end up with such a contraption in your chest?

Player: Did you really think I wouldn't notice you here, devil?

Player: You fight in the Blood War for Zariel. You'll bring the Blood War to the Coast.

Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.* *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Karlach: Fuck. I'll never get used to that. Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.
NodeContext: Ready for a fight if needed.

Player: No. No second-guessing. The devil dies - now.

Player: Claim the mace and delight in its danger.

Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark. You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance. Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now. Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months. Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will. As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface. I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You assume my people are evil, yet your research is built on sheer superstition.
Havkelaag: Enough of your kind have wreaked destruction on this plane for me to be confident in my assertion. When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible. Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue. Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: Why follow the dogma of a draconic god?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured. My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: And what if your experiment fails?
Havkelaag: If the child remains evil after the experiment is concluded, it will be destroyed. Such is the fate of all used specimens. Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse. I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

Kar'niss: And you? What are you? Apart from a torturer of lyres.

Kar'niss: A True Soul. You have more worshippers every day, majesty. Yes. Yes, they'll do nicely.

Scuttles back to standard distance at the end of the line.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player enters the camp, Wyll waiting at a side, fully in view. A diabolical circle draws itself onto the ground in front of you and Wyll, shocked/surprise, and Mizora in devil form rises from it, maybe can have a turn and a noble pose at the end.
Mizora: Sorores surge. Testis esto pacti mei.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Two more diabolical circles form, and a female devil rises from each.
Mizora: Come, Sisters, be my testament. Notum sit in Baator.
Arbiter Cirrus: Notum sit in Baator.
Narrator: *You've heard of such devils - Sisters of Justice, adjudicators of diabolical contracts and bargains.*
Wyll: Holy hells.
Player: Interesting. I don't recall sending out invitations to the Sisters of Justice.
Mizora: You do not call upon the Sisters. They come when the Hells demand witness. I come to bargain. The Hells demand witness.
Narrator: *Your parasite links with Wyll's, and your memories flow into him. He sees his father's flight from Wyrm's Rock and hears Mizora's words to you.*
Wyll: Father is dead? Godsdamned devil. Why are you here?
Mizora: Sisters.
Arbiter Cirrus: Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: A contract appears in the air, glowing. It is Wyll's contract.
Mizora: Your contract, Wyll. Signed in blood, forged in fire, bound in bone - but not unbreakable.
Player: What are you proposing?
Mizora: A life for a life. No contract is ended without sacrifice. The cost must be paid.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you. Option one. I show you the way to your father. I guarantee him no harm except that from you and your allies. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal. Option two. I break your pact, and you are freed from your duty. Your father dies by his enemy's hand, and Baldur's Gate loses its greatest champion. Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.
Player: Break the pact, Wyll. You deserve your freedom.

Viconia DeVir: You may have evaded the Mapping of the Heart, but never mind - I can delve into your true intentions right now...
Narrator: *You feel the barest of presences caress your mind - she's reading your thoughts.*
Viconia DeVir: Ah, as I thought. Quite an adventure has brought you to this point - illithids, kidnapping, infection, the Hells, hunted by cultists and githyanki alike... and of course, the artefact. You have value. Quite an adventure has brought you to this point - illithids, kidnapping, infection, the Hells, hunted by cultists and githyanki alike... and of course, the artefact.
NodeContext: Ill-ih-thids
Player: I know I have value to my patron - but what you see in me I've no idea.
Viconia DeVir: Oh but I think you do - the Mapping unearthed much more than your heartform - I saw all your secrets. I felt Shadowheart's presence in your mind, and with it, the artefact. She succeeded in retrieving it, but then it is you who appeared, not her. Where is the artefact?
Player: Why do you even want it?
Viconia DeVir: I did not consent to questions. But I suppose you have undergone a great deal to reach this place, and anything I tell you cannot compromise me now - for you will either leave on my terms, or not at all... Whispers reached my ears from all corners - potential rivals of Lady Shar, all vying for the same prize. A new god, amassing the disaffected, the outcasts - those who should turn to us. This 'Absolute' is but an upstart; disturbing the natural order and threatening to impede the glorious return of Lady Shar's pure, endless darkness. I had to act. I had to strangle that foul conspiracy while it was still in the cradle. We learned all we could - the artefact was the one thing the Absolutists feared. The one thing they desperately wanted to keep out of their enemies' grasp. I had to have it.
Player: I've heard enough.
Viconia DeVir: Then answer me - where is the artefact? I felt Shadowheart's presence in your mind, and with it, the artefact. She succeeded in retrieving it, but then it is you who appeared, not her. Where is the artefact?
Player: Say nothing.
Viconia DeVir: Too late to keep your counsel, I'm afraid. You already revealed so much to me during the Mapping. Humour me with a little negotiation. Perhaps we can find terms that will allow blades to remain sheathed.
Player: All right, you wish to negotiate? Make me an offer then.
Viconia DeVir: How about the artefact for your life? And perhaps even my support in the battles yet to come, against the Absolute?
Player: The artefact alone can't save you. Best if we unite against our common enemy - the Absolute.
Viconia DeVir: My interest is defeating the Absolute. It seems you're on that path already. I will not have it said that I am unreasonable. Shadowheart. Surrender her to me - she has much to answer for.
Player: Let me go, and I'll bring her to you.

He Who Was: The air stirs in trepidation - you have the ledger.
Player: Here - take it.
He Who Was: We have it - her lies, her guilt. Madeline reported her friends to a Dark Justiciar and fled when they were butchered. Well, she flees no more. I will be the conduit for Madeline's spirit. I will force her to face trial. And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: I am here in the honour of justice and order - that is all.
He Who Was: Then steel your heart - for this woman is a serpent who wears many faces. Do not be fooled. Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Karlach: Pot, meet kettle.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining. The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: Don't blame others for what you did.
Madeline: You didn't see it. Didn't see what the Dark Justiciar did. She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs. On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so. She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Stab yourself. Rip your stomach open. Feel the pain of your friends - only then will you be free. Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.
Madeline: Like... this?
NodeContext: Madeline draws a blade from behind her and holds it in front of her stomach, blade pointed towards her stomach. She is utterly terrified (pose like seppuku)
Player: Stop. You were willing to hurt yourself - that is enough for me.

Zethino: Violence erupts here - my home. My refuge in this city of stone and steel. Solace escapes me... Your eyes, stira. There is pain, endless and deep. But also devotion - blazing like the sun. You're in love, are you not?
Player: I do love someone - someone close to me, actually.
Zethino: You are wise to admit it. When it comes to love, vulnerability is armour. Truth, a sword. And trust, a shield. I pray you wield all three, stira. Bring the one you love to me. I will look into your hearts and see if your love is eternal. Or doomed eternally. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: How about it, Lae'zel? Want to give it a go?
Lae'zel: Yes. But be warned - I play to win.
Zethino: Lae'zel: passions of the heart and the blade wage war in her soul. Listen. Think. What does she most desire?
Player: To ascend.
Lae'zel: You know me as I know myself. Glory be to my queen.
Zethino: Hear how your bond thrums with pleasure. Strong. Vital. Pulsing with affection. The heart craves comfort, but needs respect. How does one earn the dark-haired maiden's respect?
Player: Farting on a Selûnite.
Shadowheart: I would never!
NodeContext: Mortified
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player takes a second step, moving even closer to the center for the trunk to the companion.
Zethino: The sweetest loves dance lightly on the tongue. But now we must dig deeper. Into the most painful reaches of the spirit. Shame sits in the soul of all - to tame it, we must name it. Shadowheart - what is her deepest shame?
Player: Her hair.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: # Shorter Appearance Sequence #
Wyll: Holy hells.
Player: I thought we were done with you.
Mizora: I am not so easy to be rid of. I come to bargain, and the Hells demand witness. Your father is dead, Wyll. The Dead Three have claimed their prize.
Wyll: Dead? Godsdamn wretches!
Mizora: Still yourself, pup. Not every death is forever. Sisters.
Arbiter Cirrus: Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: A contract appears in the air, glowing. It is Wyll's contract.
Mizora: Your contract, Wyll. Signed in blood, forged in fire, bound in bone - but not unbreakable.
Player: Then break it already. Wyll doesn't need to wait six months.
Mizora: No contract is ended without sacrifice. A cost must be paid.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you. Option one. I show you the way to your father. I guarantee him no harm except that from you and your allies. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal. Option two. I break your pact, and you are freed from your duty. Your father dies by his enemy's hand, and Baldur's Gate loses its greatest champion. Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!
Mizora: Silence, Karlach!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.
Player: Let your father die. When the city's free, you can take his place.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: [opening, face-to-face]

Wyll and Karlach stand facing one another, fists clenched.

Wyll and Karlach stand facing one another, fists clenched.
Karlach: Well I'll be godsdamned - the Blade of Frontiers. Thought I'd shaken you for good. That'll teach me to underestimate you.
Shadowheart: You two have met before, I take it?
Karlach: If by 'met' you mean hoofing it through the Hells with this fucker on my tail. Look - it's an honour to be chased by a famed hero. I'm no devil, though. Not by a long shot.
Wyll: I've hunted you to the Hells and beyond. It ends here, Karlach.
Karlach: For fuck's sake, you must be half troll to have a skull that thick. If you'd just hear me out -
Narrator: *A great fire roars through you - the fire of the First Hell.* *Her rage and desperation seep into you. She is a victim of the Blood War, not an agent of it.*
Karlach: Fuck. I'll never get used to that. Look, whatever else it may be, the tadpole isn't a liar. I never wanted to serve Zariel, and I escaped the first chance I could. So stand down.
NodeContext: Ready for a fight if needed.
Lae'zel: Control yourself, Wyll. I understand bloodthirst. But this is no time to quench it.
Shadowheart: Let's take things down a notch, shall we? She's no devil, Wyll. You'll have to look elsewhere to find fodder for your blade.
Wyll: You don't know what this means. You don't know what you're asking me to do.
Karlach: I'm asking you to live, Wyll. I don't want to hurt you. And, to be frank, I'd rather not find out how the Blade got his name. I swear to you, on all I am, I'm not what you think.
Narrator: *Two souls hang in the balance. Kill Karlach, fulfil your contract - and condemn a possible innocent to the Hells. Or spare her and face the repercussions with Mizora.*
Wyll: Save your breath. Let's see if this devil bleeds.

Vlaakith: So - it is found.
NodeContext: Vlaakith should sligjhtly overpronounce every word, think Davros from Doctor Who, each syllable drips with a kind of mad, ancient evil
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The planecaster vibrates, shaking the ground around it.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Vlaakith gha'g shkath zai!
NodeContext: pronounced VLAH-kith gawg shkaath ZAI (meaning 'For the honour of Vlaakith!')
Lae'zel: My queen.
Narrator: *Your vision throbs with ink-black darkness as your patron borrows your gaze - beholding the vision in front of you.* *Not exactly a god - but not far off. Your patron recoils, but not before leaving a word of advice - caution.*
Vlaakith: You are permitted to look upon me. You are invited to kneel.
Player: Who exactly are you?
Vlaakith: Who... am... I? I am Vlaakith. Undying Queen of the noble githyanki. God Regent of the Six Arms of Tu'narath. AND YOU...
NodeContext: she loses her shit here, before collecting herself
Vlaakith: You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: Friend - I came to bring it back to you.
Gale: How generous of you - but perhaps you've forgotten we need it ourselves? That thing is keeping us safe.
Vlaakith: An unexpected servant. Your will is strong. You have ventured far from your kind's comforts to serve us. Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning. The Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I shall cleanse it for you, my queen. Tell me how.
InternalNodeContext: He's not altogether sure why this task is falling to the player and not to him, but also doesn't want to challenge his queen's motivations.
Vlaakith: SILENCE, W'wargaz. There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight. They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire. As long as they live, the Prism is compromised. Find the one inside and destroy them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed.
Player: I will do as you wish.

Counsellor Florrick: Wyll? What has become of you?
Player: Calm down, this cell was trivial to unlock. Getting out of here will be easy.
Counsellor Florrick: You don't get it. We lost. I came seeking allies to our cause. Watchers spotted me, dragged me to Ulder Ravengard's husk. Empty as a stare. Your father's a tadpole's puppet, Wyll. Nothing more. Empty as a stare. A tadpole's puppet, nothing more. He spoke in accusations. Apostasy, conspiracy, sedition. I will soon be hanged on the city gallows to a chorus of cheers. You might have unlocked my cell, but there's no escape from this place.
Wyll: The Hells with that. Nothing is over. Not while I still draw breath.
Player: I'm breaking you out. With Ravengard gone, Baldur's Gate needs you. Gorion's Ward overcame great odds to protect the city. You can do the same.
Counsellor Florrick: 'When the people need a miracle, you cannot wait for the gods to answer.'
Wyll: Father's words.
Counsellor Florrick: Indeed. To think I'd almost forgotten. No more sulking. I know what to do. And I can only do it with the help of the Blade. No more sulking. I know what to do. Unlock my cell, escort me out of Wyrm's Rock. I'll seek out my connections. When the city's streets shatter, you'll want their blades.
Player: I won't help you.

Vlaakith: Not merely great, Lae'zel. Eternal.

Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Nere mentioned that you were seeking access to the Temple. Looks like you found it.
Balthazar: Perhaps you'd be more useful dead than alive if you don't even know what I'm seeking here. But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Nere mentioned that you were seeking access to the Temple. Looks like you found it.
Balthazar: Perhaps you'd be more useful dead than alive if you don't even know what I'm seeking here. But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create. General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall. You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: I received permission. Take it up with your peers at Moonrise, if you have an issue.
Balthazar: ...Fine. I'll forgive your transgressions this time - there are much grander things at stake.
NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course. Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Player: I'm called Daisy Dewdrop Fluffington.
GROUP_SteelWatchers: Well met, citizen Fluffington.
Narrator: *Your parasite stirs. From the construct, you feel connection. Resonance.*
Player: What in the hells is that thing?

Gauntlet Edwynna: State your business.
Player: I was born and raised in Baldur's Gate. This is my home.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Uh-huh. Eyes open, body still.

Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark. You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance. Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now. Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months. Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will. As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface. I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You're letting your personal biases affect your method. Why assume they're evil?
Havkelaag: I assume nothing. Innate githyanki cruelty is an established fact - no doubt you witnessed it yourself in the retrieval of the egg itself. When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible. Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue. Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: What's the Ptarian code?
Havkelaag: A series of moral imperatives bestowed by the great dragon-deity Bahamut. In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured. My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: An experiment like this will only confirm the surface dwellers' suspicion of us.
Havkelaag: Of course it won't. If anything, it will do quite the opposite. The academic institutions up here will finally be forced to take us seriously. Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.

Counsellor Florrick: You're too late. It's over.
Jaheira: Florrick? What have they done to you?
Counsellor Florrick: I don't speak of myself, High Harper. I speak of the city itself - we came too late. It's over.
Player: So you're giving up, just like that?
Counsellor Florrick: I didn't give up. I lost. I came seeking allies to our cause. Watchers spotted me, dragged me to Ulder Ravengard's husk. Empty as a stare. Your father's a tadpole's puppet, Wyll. Nothing more. Empty as a stare. A tadpole's puppet, nothing more. He spoke in accusations. Apostasy, conspiracy, sedition. I'll be executed in five dawns. You might have unlocked my cell, but there's no escape from this place.
Jaheira: The Fist can go hang themselves - we're getting you out.
Player: Ravengard's dead. The city needs you - I'm getting you out.
Counsellor Florrick: He's - dead? So perishes the city. I can - I can scarcely bear it. Forget it. Baldur's Gate's good as cinder. An illithid hive beyond saving.
Narrator: *You recall the tales of Gorion's Ward, the great hero of Baldur's Gate. Without them, the city would have succumbed to war, famine, and worse.*
Player: Fine, turn your back. I don't need you.

Wyll: Let my father die. When the city's free, I'll take his place.

Arabella: I don't see any - wait. Here they come! Sorry. Knocks the wind right out of me.
Player: Normally tales of stolen artefacts are tragedies - I'm glad you've bucked that trend.
Arabella: Tragedies? Them's the sad ones, right? I hope not. 'Specially since mum and pops - After Zevlor - When he - Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran. I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't.
Narrator: *You notice the girl shivering in fear and anger. She is not yet ready to hear the truth of her parents' fate.*
Player: I'll think about it. My hands are full with these cultists.
Arabella: Fine. Whatever. I don't need you - I'll find them myself!
Player: I've rarely seen corpses as violated as theirs are - it was quite the sight.
Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.
Player: And are you tough enough?
Arabella: I'll prove it. Let me help in the camp, til you bring mom and pops back to me. Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!
Player: I was just poking at the rancid dog-meat of your parents' corpses.
Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.
Player: I'm telling the truth: you don't want to find them.
Arabella: Then what... what is even left for me to do?
Player: Live, grow up, and make your path anew by my side.
Arabella: I don't want to forget about them... I can't. To the hells with your camp, and to the hells with you.

Gauntlet Edwynna: Halt! By orders of Lord Gortash, refugees are no longer allowed in the city. Turn around.
Player: I'm not a refugee.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Well, do you have the means to support yourself? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: I can take care of myself. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Gauntlet Edwynna: Right. Article 30.1.5 of the Council's Decree on Extraordinary Wartime Measures. I am confiscating that. The city thanks you for your contribution. Your name?
Player: I'm called Daisy Dewdrop Fluffington.
GROUP_SteelWatchers: Well met, citizen Fluffington.
Narrator: *Your parasite stirs. From the construct, you feel connection. Resonance.*
Player: What in the hells is that thing?
GROUP_SteelWatchers: I am a Steel Watcher, citizen. Here to serve the people of Baldur's Gate in the name of Lord Enver Gortash.
Gauntlet Edwynna: State your business.
Wyll: My good lady. I am Wyll Ravengard. My business is the city's business.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Wyll Ravengard? Of course, of course - the city is always open to you. But I'm afraid you'll still need to comply with new protocol. By Lord Gortash's command.
Player: Baldur's Gate is my city, my home.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Uh-huh. Eyes open, body still.
NodeContext: "Uh-huh" as in, "Yes, I heard you and am going with it."
Player: Do as she says. Stand still.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The steel watcher steps forward and begins to scan the player's eyes.
There is NO mindmeld, because player is NOT tadpoled. ?

Narrator: *Behind the Watcher's gaze, a presence awakens. You are seen, you are known.* *Your infernal machinery seems to snap to attention, almost singing in recognition.*
Karlach: Whoa. My engine. It's almost... I don't know. Buzzing. Like it's paying attention.
Narrator: *Your party's prior transgressions are reflected in its stare, as witnessed by the cult's ever-alert scrying eyes.* *It has heard the howls of slaughtered goblins.* *It has seen the deep shadows of Grymforge, and the stone floors left bloodied.* *It knows the cold walls of Moonrise Towers, and the cultists who fell there.* *The Watcher speaks directly into your mind with a voice like poisoned honey.*
GROUP_SteelWatchers: You are marked for special treatment. A defective Steel Watcher. Not simply an enemy of the people, but an enemy of the Absolute. Come quietly, or die. You are marked for special treatment. Not simply an enemy of the people, but an enemy of the Absolute. Come quietly, or die.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Mindmeld with steel watcher ends
Player: Ready yourself for a fight.

Alfira: You're all right! Thank goodness, I was worried they'd got you too.
NodeContext: Relieved. Trying to be cheerful but you're upset, and just holding it together.
Player: Of course I am. As if there was any doubt.
Alfira: I'm afraid doubt is all I know these days. I still can't believe it. The cultists. The screams... I had to watch my friends, people who can barely hold a sword, try to fight a pack of murderous zealots. All I could do was run.
Player: What did the cultists do to the others?
Alfira: I don't know. It just... happened so quickly. How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: I'll let you know when I figure it out.
Alfira: We're in the same boat, then? That's... somewhat of a comfort. You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there. If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

Viconia DeVir: You and I need to speak... Unless, of course, you are intent on attacking me again? I would not advise it.
Jaheira: You've finally found yourself a following, Mother Superior. And you only had to hollow out their heads to do it.
Minsc: Pin your eyes to the treacherous she-drow. Do not focus on the many, many others - Boo will handle them.

Viconia DeVir: Always a pleasure to see old acquaintances. But you would be wise to not interfere in this matter.
Player: We already spoke - if you can call that 'Mapping' farce a conversation.
Viconia DeVir: A necessary ruse - one that allowed me to seek out your true intentions. The House of Grief attracts all manner of people, but only some have value to Lady Shar. You have value. Quite an adventure has brought you to this point - illithids, kidnapping, infection, the Hells, hunted by cultists and githyanki alike... and of course, the artefact.
NodeContext: Ill-ih-thids
Player: I know I have value to my patron - but what you see in me I've no idea.
Viconia DeVir: Oh but I think you do - the Mapping unearthed much more than your heartform - I saw all your secrets. I felt Shadowheart's presence in your mind, and with it, the artefact. She succeeded in retrieving it, but then it is you who appeared, not her. Where is the artefact?
Player: Why do you even want it?
Viconia DeVir: I did not consent to questions. But I suppose you have undergone a great deal to reach this place, and anything I tell you cannot compromise me now - for you will either leave on my terms, or not at all... Whispers reached my ears from all corners - potential rivals of Lady Shar, all vying for the same prize. A new god, amassing the disaffected, the outcasts - those who should turn to us. This 'Absolute' is but an upstart; disturbing the natural order and threatening to impede the glorious return of Lady Shar's pure, endless darkness. I had to act. I had to strangle that foul conspiracy while it was still in the cradle. We learned all we could - the artefact was the one thing the Absolutists feared. The one thing they desperately wanted to keep out of their enemies' grasp. I had to have it.
Player: You thought you could best the Absolute? The githyanki?
Viconia DeVir: To fight so many foes openly could prove unwise. Shar's children are better deployed as daggers in the shadows, not massed upon a battlefield. So let the others fight, while we wait. Once they are spent and bloodied from each other, we would slip in and take the prize. Alas, most of those I sent, perished. All but one - Shadowheart.
Narrator: *Viconia trails off, holding your gaze with a dark, hungry look. She has staked everything on acquiring the Astral Prism.*
Viconia DeVir: I felt Shadowheart's presence in your mind, and with it, the artefact. She succeeded in retrieving it, but then it is you who appeared, not her. Where is the artefact?
Player: Say nothing.
Viconia DeVir: Too late to keep your counsel, I'm afraid. You already revealed so much to me during the Mapping. Humour me with a little negotiation. Perhaps we can find terms that will allow blades to remain sheathed.
Player: All right, you wish to negotiate? Make me an offer then.
Viconia DeVir: How about the artefact for your life? And perhaps even my support in the battles yet to come, against the Absolute?
Player: Shar will allow you to make such an offer?
Viconia DeVir: My Lady ... she does not heed this new threat. This Absolute. Perhaps she is above such mortal concerns, but I must preserve her church, even if she does not ask me to. When I deal with the Absolute, my standing with Lady Shar will be stronger than ever. My rightful place is at her right hand, and I will remain there. I will not be replaced by Shadow...
Narrator: *You suddenly realise what has been troubling her. Shar has rewarded her loyalty by forcing her to groom her own replacement - Shadowheart.*
Player: Not happening. Even if I wanted to give it to you, I can't. The artefact is bound to me. It will kill you.
Viconia DeVir: My interest is defeating the Absolute. It seems you're on that path already. I will not have it said that I am unreasonable. Shadowheart. Surrender her to me - she has much to answer for.
Player: Let me go, and I'll bring her to you.

Counsellor Florrick: Leave me. It's over.
Player: Oh, don't be dramatic. I could unlock this cell blindfolded - you'll be out in no time.
Counsellor Florrick: You don't get it. We lost. I came seeking allies to our cause. Watchers spotted me, dragged me to Ulder Ravengard's husk. Empty as a stare. Your father's a tadpole's puppet, Wyll. Nothing more. Empty as a stare. A tadpole's puppet, nothing more. He spoke in accusations. Apostasy, conspiracy, sedition. I'll be executed in five dawns. You might have unlocked my cell, but there's no escape from this place.
Wyll: The Hells with that. Nothing is over. Not while I still draw breath.
Player: Ravengard's dead. The city needs you - I'm getting you out.
Counsellor Florrick: He's - dead? So perishes the city. I can - I can scarcely bear it. Forget it. Baldur's Gate's good as cinder. An illithid hive beyond saving.
Narrator: *You recall the tales of Gorion's Ward, the great hero of Baldur's Gate. Without them, the city would have succumbed to war, famine, and worse.*
Player: I pull you from flames, and this is how you repay me? Find your courage and fight!
Counsellor Florrick: 'When the people need a miracle, you cannot wait for the gods to answer.'
Wyll: Father's words.
Counsellor Florrick: Indeed. To think I'd almost forgotten. No more sulking. I know what to do. And I can only do it with the help of the Blade. No more sulking. I know what to do. Lead me from my cell, escort me out of Wyrm's Rock. I'll seek out my connections. When the city's streets shatter, you'll want their blades.
Player: I won't help you.

Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you. Option one. I raise your father from the dead. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal. Option two. I break your pact, and you are freed from your duty. Your father remains dead, and Baldur's Gate loses its greatest champion. Name your sacrifice.

Mizora: Silence, Karlach!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.
Player: Let your father die. When the city's free, you can take his place.

Arabella: Sorry. Knocks the wind right out of me.

Arabella: Mm. Maybe. But you gotta help me first. Me and mum and pops, we followed Zevlor out here. Then he - he - Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran. I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't. Still can't find 'em - but I bet you can. You'll help me, I just know it!

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Hail, friend. Fine day, isn't it? Forgive me - you're in no mood to talk about the weather. Your journey here was a hard one, no doubt.
 Is this your first time in Baldur's Gate?
Player: I've passed through, but I'm a Waterdeep man at heart.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: A word of advice then - you might not get as warm a welcome as in days gone by. Used to be you'd arrive knowing you'd a full belly and a warm bed waiting for you. Not any more. These days, there's barely enough to go around. Add the refugees on top and... well, folk aren't feeling too generous.
Player: Is there anything I can do to ease these people's burden?
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: I've been asking myself the same question. I wouldn't be the first to interfere. Some well-to-do's in the city donated enough to see the newcomers right for the time being. Only they didn't bother helping everyone else. Locals going without while strangers feast - it's stoked the fire, all right. Some Baldurians are kicking up a fuss round the front of the barn as we speak. If I wasn't wearing this uniform, I'd walk round there and teach them a lesson they'd never forget.
Player: I'm all in favour of re-education. It sounds like they have a lot to learn.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: I knew you'd feel the same way. We need to march round the front, and kill every last one of them. Let's see them eat our food with their guts on the floor. What do you say?
Player: You're speaking my language. I'm in.

Lorroakan: You have a job to do. So do it - quickly.
Player: You must be the wizard Lorroakan. I've heard a great deal about you.
Lorroakan: My - could it be? Gale of Waterdeep, here in my tower. I'm surprised you dare show your face after Mystra cast you on the scrap heap. Well don't stand on ceremony - out with it.
Player: I seek a certain rare tome - concerning Karsus.
Lorroakan: You're quite in luck, then - see Tolna downstairs. One such tome is amongst our rarest books. But enough of dusty history - I look to the future. You know I seek the Nightsong. Do you have it or not?
Player: What do you want with her?
Lorroakan: 'She'. Then you do know her. You've been to Shar's temple. To the Shadowfell. You've looked upon the Nightsong's face. Tell me - and choose your next words carefully - where is she now?
Player: Why do you want her so badly?
Lorroakan: I'm growing tired of this repartee, my friend. Let us cut to the chase. Beautiful, isn't it? Worth more than your life, too. I bought it from a Calishite warlock with very little of his soul left to him. It can bind a celestial to the wearer's service with a snap of the fingers. And this? This can keep her in place. Forever.
Player: I know where she is. I might even be willing to tell you.
Gale: You'd give up her location, just like that? You're not actually considering betraying her, are you...?
Nightwarden Minthara: Surrendering a powerful ally to this preening wizard does not seem wise.
Halsin: You broke Dame Aylin's shackles once before. Do not help this one to forge new ones for her.
Lorroakan: Good. Then you'll have no trouble fulfilling the contract to bring the Nightsong here.

Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Nere mentioned that you were seeking access to the Temple. Looks like you found it.
Balthazar: Perhaps you'd be more useful dead than alive if you don't even know what I'm seeking here. But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Enlighten me. Fine, consider your merits acknowledged. Care to enlighten me as to what's going on?
Balthazar: There is a relic here. One which General Thorm desires. No - needs. I will retrieve it for him... ...and you will help me. Ignorant you may be, you've shown some prowess in scouting and combat by making it this far. While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him might just be the best way to gain access to Moonrise Towers.* *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?
Balthazar: Telling you will not make the task any less perilous. Just obey, and use your ignorance as a shield. You should be adept at that already. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work... Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

He Who Was: Madeline's spirit is within reach. It is time to make her face trial, to make her suffer. And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: When punishment is needed, my hand will not shy from the blade.
He Who Was: The raven was right, we were fated to meet. Break her, my friend - most thoroughly. Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Wyll: Not as if you can relate to the killing urge, can you? Hmph - I can taste the hypocrisy from here.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining. The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: If it was drunk complaining, why did you report them?
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar said to report everythin', big or small. She ain't the type you say no to. She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs. On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so. She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.
Madeline: Like... this?
NodeContext: Madeline draws a blade from behind her and holds it in front of her stomach, blade pointed towards her stomach. She is utterly terrified (pose like seppuku)
Player: Start stabbing, and don't stop until I say so.
Madeline: Ah! I'm sorry.
NodeContext: Ah! is a noise of pain as she stabs herself in the stomach and then pulls out the knife. 'I'm sorry' is said in clear pain.
Madeline: Argh. I'm so sorry.
NodeContext: stabs herself again on 'Argh', noise of pain. I'm so so sorry is half crying as she's in agony.
Player: Stop. You've done enough.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face. Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: Another True Soul was looking for you. Nere - I aided him in the Underdark.
Balthazar: Ah, it was you who pulled his sorry carcass from the rubble. You should have left him there. The miserable worm tried to kill me, hoping to take all the glory of this mission for himself. Dull, dull, dull. Nere was never cut out to be a True Soul - he's a very obedient corpse, though. Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Z'rell spoke of a relic - something called the Nightsong in your notes. They were very interesting. Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: I received permission. Take it up with your peers at Moonrise, if you have an issue.
Balthazar: ...Fine. I'll forgive your transgressions this time - there are much grander things at stake.
NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course. Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?

Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.

Counsellor Florrick: Leave me. It's over.
Player: I don't understand. What do you mean?
Counsellor Florrick: I came seeking allies to our cause. Watchers spotted me, dragged me to Ulder Ravengard's husk. Empty as a stare. Your father's a tadpole's puppet, Wyll. Nothing more. Empty as a stare. A tadpole's puppet, nothing more. He spoke in accusations. Apostasy, conspiracy, sedition. I'll be executed in five dawns. You might have unlocked my cell, but there's no escape from this place.
Wyll: The Hells with that. Nothing is over. Not while I still draw breath.
Player: Pathetic. I'm getting you out so I can beat some sense into you.
Counsellor Florrick: Then beat me. Take my head, leave me rotting. Death is already my fate. Forget it. Baldur's Gate's good as cinder. An illithid hive beyond saving.
Narrator: *You recall the tales of Gorion's Ward, the great hero of Baldur's Gate. Without them, the city would have succumbed to war, famine, and worse.*
Player: Coward. Balduran didn't build the Gate for you to weep as it burns. Gorion's Ward overcame great odds to protect the city. You can do the same.
Counsellor Florrick: 'When the people need a miracle, you cannot wait for the gods to answer.' Ulder's words. I'd almost forgotten. No more sulking. I know what to do. Lead me from my cell, escort me out of Wyrm's Rock. I'll seek out my connections. When the city's streets shatter, you'll want their blades.
Player: I won't help you.

Varsh Ko'kuu: You can tell Kith'rak Therezzyn that my position has not changed: the egg requires more time. Furthermore - oh.
NodeContext: You turn on 'Furthermore' expecting to see an angry guard, but you're surprised to find the player - a complete stranger.
Varsh Ko'kuu: I was not expecting an istik. What brings you to my hatchery? Still, I suppose a guest in our crèche can be allowed some understanding. What brings you to my hatchery?
Player: I heard you're waiting for one last egg to hatch.
Lae'zel: Failure at the first hurdle of existence. Most caretakers would crush it and be done.
Varsh Ko'kuu: Most caretakers would not give the child its fair chance, but I shall. There could be greatness in that shell.
Narrator: *You note that the hope in his voice is tinged with weariness. It's the voice of a man who's fought the inevitable for a long time.*
Player: Tell me the truth. Why do you really care about this one so much?
Varsh Ko'kuu: Not all that arrive late are weak. I created this entire hatchery, despite being the last of my clutch to hatch. They almost drowned me in the hatching pool. If it wasn't for the varsh of my clutch - This one deserves the same chance.
Player: This seems like an awful lot of fuss for one egg.
Varsh Ko'kuu: Kith'rak Therezzyn is of the same opinion. She would see it destroyed and forgotten. I'll give it a while longer, and if it doesn't hatch - it will have proven her right.
Player: Why risk its life at all? Give it to me - I'll take care of it.
Varsh Ko'kuu: You? What do you know about githyanki child-rearing? Still, the captain's due for an inspection any day now, and if she sees it here...
NodeContext: the captain will destroy his precious egg if she finds it
Varsh Ko'kuu: Tell me, what will you do with it if I entrust it to you?
Player: Depends, how much do you think these things sell for?

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith turns to player and looms over them instead.
Vlaakith: Child of Gith. You carry what is mine. Do I call you loyal servant - or thief? Istik. You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: I didn't take the weapon from you, but I am returning it.
Vlaakith: An unexpected servant. Your will is strong. Descendant of noble dragons - you honour us with your allyship. Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning. That 'weapon' you carry - the Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Lae'zel: I will cleanse it for you, my Queen. Tell me how.
Vlaakith: There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight. They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire. As long as they live, the Prism is compromised. Kill them. Do this, and I will cleanse you and your allies. Do this - - and ascend.
Lae'zel: Ascension? My queen. An honour gained, a burden borne. Choose. But know this: the cost of refusal is great.
Vlaakith: Not merely great, Lae'zel. Eternal.

Vlaakith: Perhaps I misheard. You would not speak ill of a god. Would you?
Lae'zel: Do not test her. She will be our ruin.
Player: I spoke too hastily - please forgive me.

Alfira: First cultists nearly murder us, and now we have a traitor on the inside? Can't we trust anyone?
NodeContext: frustrated and tired of being scared
Player: Cultists? What happened?
Alfira: Stars, you hadn't heard?
 We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Someone told them to rot in the Nine Hells, that we weren't going anywhere. Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: How did you survive?
Alfira: Some of us fought back - or tried to. But it was hopeless. All I could do was run.
Player: Only fools fight an ambush. Better to live and strike another day - preferably to the neck.
Alfira: That means a lot, coming from you. You always seem to take everything in your stride. How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: I'll let you know when I figure it out.
Alfira: We're in the same boat, then? That's... somewhat of a comfort. You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there. If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic. Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: Glad I could be of help.
Halsin: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless... ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn. But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do... How is this possible...?
Player: I think this artefact has something to do with it.
Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world. You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know. I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them. Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected. I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help. I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from. That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: So all of this was for nothing.
Halsin: Patience. I can't just snap my fingers... but I know where the solution almost certainly lies. I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers. Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic. If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: You seem to know a lot about this. Will you come with me to Moonrise?
Halsin: I wish I could, but there's still work I've yet to finish - blood I've yet to spill. I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise. I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Look around you - there's no order anymore. Only chaos.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural. Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.
 Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut. They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: You ask too much of me. I can't help you.

Player: I'm glad you made it too, it's one hell of a curse.
Alfira: It wasn't the curse that did us in. We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Someone told them to rot in the Nine Hells, that we weren't going anywhere. Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: I'm so sorry.
Alfira: It just... it just never stops. Rolan, of all people, saved us. He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: I know - Rolan isn't happy with me.
Alfira: Can you blame him? His brother and sister are gone. He's... dealing with it as best he can. We all are. How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: It helps to remember what is at stake - I fight for nature, for balance. I fight for life itself.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then. You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there. If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.
