Zethino: Your bond beats in pleasure. It is an honour to behold. The heart craves comfort, but needs respect. How does one earn the dark-haired maiden's respect?
Player: Being kind to animals.
Shadowheart: Not completely off the mark, but there's easier paths into my good graces...
Zethino: There is a hollowness between you, something brittle and strained. We must dig deeper. Grasp the pain hiding within. Shame sits in the soul of all - to tame it, we must name it. Shadowheart - what is her deepest shame?
Player: Her hair.

Counsellor Florrick: You might as well lock the cell. You're too late. It's over.
Jaheira: Florrick? What have they done to you?
Counsellor Florrick: I don't speak of myself, High Harper. I speak of the city itself - we came too late. It's over.
Player: You're talking drivel. I'm getting you out of here.
Counsellor Florrick: You don't get it. We lost. I came seeking allies to our cause. Watchers spotted me, dragged me to Ulder Ravengard's husk. Empty as a stare. Your father's a tadpole's puppet, Wyll. Nothing more. Empty as a stare. A tadpole's puppet, nothing more. He spoke in accusations. Apostasy, conspiracy, sedition. I will soon be hanged on the city gallows to a chorus of cheers. You might have unlocked my cell, but there's no escape from this place.
Wyll: The Hells with that. Nothing is over. Not while I still draw breath.
Player: Pathetic. I'm getting you out so I can beat some sense into you.
Counsellor Florrick: Heh - I'll give you credit. I'm drowning in tears, and you hold out a fist. Ulder would've done the same. 'When the people need a miracle', he said, 'you cannot wait for the gods to answer.' I'd almost forgotten. No more sulking. I know what to do. Lead me from my cell, escort me out of Wyrm's Rock. I'll seek out my connections. When the city's streets shatter, you'll want their blades.
Player: I won't help you.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player enters the camp, Wyll waiting at a side, fully in view. A diabolical circle draws itself onto the ground in front of you and Wyll, shocked/surprise, and Mizora in devil form rises from it, maybe can have a turn and a noble pose at the end.
Mizora: Sorores surge. Testis esto pacti mei.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Two more diabolical circles form, and a female devil rises from each.
Mizora: Come, Sisters, be my testament. Notum sit in Baator.
Arbiter Cirrus: Notum sit in Baator.
Wyll: Holy hells.
Player: Please, introduce me to your friends.
Mizora: Feena, Cirrus. Arbiters for the Hells, exemplars of justice. I come to bargain. The Hells demand witness.
Narrator: *Your parasite links with Wyll's, and your memories flow into him. He sees his father's flight from Wyrm's Rock and hears Mizora's words to you.*
Wyll: Father is dead? Godsdamned devil. Why are you here?
Mizora: Sisters.
Arbiter Cirrus: Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus. Infernus contractus te vocamus.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: A contract appears in the air, glowing. It is Wyll's contract.
Mizora: Your contract, Wyll. Signed in blood, forged in fire, bound in bone - but not unbreakable.
Player: Then break it already. Wyll has suffered enough.
Mizora: No contract is ended without sacrifice. A cost must be paid.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you. Option one. I raise your father from the dead. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal. Option two. I break your pact, and you are freed from your duty. Your father remains dead, and Baldur's Gate loses its greatest champion. Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!
Mizora: Silence, Karlach!
Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.
Player: Leave him dead. When the city's free, you can take his place.

Corsair Greymon: Well I'll be ploughed sideways - we got a welcoming party.
Morghal: You shithead - time you showed up. We got trouble.
NodeContext: Projected voice
Corsair Greymon: Spit it out. Sergeant finally choked on True Soul Nere's prick?
NodeContext: Projected voice
Morghal: Drugh no. The Twat-Soul caused a rockfall. Trapped tighter than a ring on a fat finger.
NodeContext: DRUGH NO = FUCK NO. "Droog" like 'good', not 'food'.
Corsair Greymon: You're shitting me. He pay up?
Morghal: That's the trouble - he's got the gold on him. Sergeant's arm is falling off with all the gnome slaves she's been beating. Who's the hoon, Greymon - another slave for the dig?
Player: You keep slaves here?
Stone Guard Orgarth: Deep gnomes, mostly. Easy to feed, fat thumbs for digging.
Morghal: That a problem for you?
Player: If there's a mark on those gnomes, it will be.
Morghal: Shit. You think a runt like you's gonna... nngh...
Narrator: *You feel the slightest of stirrings in your head. The duergar is not infected, yet your minds resonate.*
Morghal: I'll be - you ain't shittin'. Felt the tingle. In that case, let's talk business. Your Twat-Soul friend Nere caused a rockfall. Trapped tighter than a hornet's arse.
Stone Guard Orgarth: Coupla gnome slaves stuck with him too, little bastards.
Morghal: You Absolute-shaggers owe us a crap-load of coin. You want through? Make a donation. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: Did you say you keep slaves here? I've got no use for slavers. Including you.
Morghal: You'll work through it, jargh. Now pay up - don't got all day. You Absolute-shaggers owe us a crap-load of coin. You want through? Make a donation. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: Did you say you keep slaves here? Forget I mentioned it.
Morghal: Fine. Now pay the toll, jargh. I'm tired of your face. You Absolute-shaggers owe us a crap-load of coin. You want through? Make a donation. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: Did you say you keep slaves here? Is that a threat? Because that is a problem.
Morghal: I don't make threats - I educate. Now hand over the coin and get moving. You Absolute-shaggers owe us a crap-load of coin. You want through? Make a donation. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: I don't think you understand - I'm gutting you here and now.

Counsellor Florrick: You're too late.
InternalNodeContext: Player inside the cell
Counsellor Florrick: It's over.
Wyll: By Avernus - Florrick.
Counsellor Florrick: Wyll? Is that you? What curse has befallen you? No matter. The city, the future. It's done.
Player: So you're giving up, just like that?
Counsellor Florrick: I didn't give up. I lost. I came seeking allies to our cause. Watchers spotted me, dragged me to Ulder Ravengard's husk. Empty as a stare. Your father's a tadpole's puppet, Wyll. Nothing more. Empty as a stare. A tadpole's puppet, nothing more. He spoke in accusations. Apostasy, conspiracy, sedition. I will soon be hanged on the city gallows to a chorus of cheers. You might have unlocked my cell, but there's no escape from this place.
Wyll: The Hells with that. Nothing is over. Not while I still draw breath.
Player: I'm breaking you out. With Ravengard gone, Baldur's Gate needs you. Gorion's Ward overcame great odds to protect the city. You can do the same.
Counsellor Florrick: 'When the people need a miracle, you cannot wait for the gods to answer.'
Wyll: Father's words.
Counsellor Florrick: Indeed. To think I'd almost forgotten. No more sulking. I know what to do. And I can only do it with the help of the Blade. No more sulking. I know what to do. Unlock my cell, escort me out of Wyrm's Rock. I'll seek out my connections. When the city's streets shatter, you'll want their blades.
Player: I won't help you.

Vlaakith: So - it is found.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The planecaster vibrates, shaking the ground around it.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Flares of light curl up in its centre and grow to full form.
Vlaakith appears, awesome and terrible, at least twice the size of any human, a hologram in a haze of astral flares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Vlaakith gha'g shkath zai!
NodeContext: pronounced VLAH-kith gawg shkaath ZAI (meaning 'For the honour of Vlaakith!')
Lae'zel: My Queen - shkath zai!
NodeContext: shkaath ZAI - for the honour!
Vlaakith: You are permitted to look upon me. You are invited to kneel.
Lae'zel: The Deathless Queen has spoken. You will obey.
Player: Kneel before Vlaakith, your queen.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player kneels, head bowed, solemn, appropriate. Vlaakith offers something resembling a smile, and gestures for the player to rise. Everyone present rises.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith looms in to face Lae'zel at their eye level.
Vlaakith: Your choice of allies is most vexing. They do not become you. Lae'zel.
Lae'zel: Ch'mar, zal'a Vlaakith. You know me.
Vlaakith: Urlon of K'liir speaks most highly. As did Al'chaia before him. You seek purity. I may yet grant it.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith turns to player and looms over them instead.
Vlaakith: Istik. You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: I didn't take the weapon from you, but I am returning it.
Vlaakith: An unexpected servant. Your will is strong. You have ventured far from your kind's comforts to serve us. Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning. That 'weapon' you carry - the Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Lae'zel: I will cleanse it for you, my Queen. Tell me how.
Vlaakith: There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight. They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire. As long as they live, the Prism is compromised. Kill them. Do this, and I will cleanse you and your allies. Do this - - and ascend.
Lae'zel: Ascension? My queen. An honour gained, a burden borne. Choose. But know this: the cost of refusal is great.
Vlaakith: Not merely great, Lae'zel. Eternal.
Player: Can't you kill them yourself? I thought 'gods' were all-powerful.
Vlaakith: Perhaps I misheard. You would not speak ill of a god. Would you?
Lae'zel: Do not test her. She will be our ruin.
Player: I spoke too hastily - please forgive me.

Viconia DeVir: You and I need to speak... Unless, of course, you are intent on attacking me again? I would not advise it.
Jaheira: You've finally found yourself a following, Mother Superior. And you only had to hollow out their heads to do it.
Minsc: Pin your eyes to the treacherous she-drow. Do not focus on the many, many others - Boo will handle them.

Player: We already spoke - if you can call that 'Mapping' farce a conversation.
Viconia DeVir: A necessary ruse - one that allowed me to seek out your true intentions. The House of Grief attracts all manner of people, but only some have value to Lady Shar. You have value. Quite an adventure has brought you to this point - illithids, kidnapping, infection, the Hells, hunted by cultists and githyanki alike... and of course, the artefact.
NodeContext: Ill-ih-thids
Player: It's called an Astral Prism. And let me guess - you want it. An old song, take my word for it.
Viconia DeVir: Its name does not concern me. Its power does. I have been awaiting word of this item for some time, ever since I dispatched a cadre of Lady Shar's children to retrieve it. I have been very patient, but no more. I felt Shadowheart's presence in your mind, and with it, the artefact. She succeeded in retrieving it, but then it is you who appeared, not her. Where is the artefact?
Player: Why do you even want it?
Viconia DeVir: I did not consent to questions. But I suppose you have undergone a great deal to reach this place, and anything I tell you cannot compromise me now - for you will either leave on my terms, or not at all... Whispers reached my ears from all corners - potential rivals of Lady Shar, all vying for the same prize. A new god, amassing the disaffected, the outcasts - those who should turn to us. This 'Absolute' is but an upstart; disturbing the natural order and threatening to impede the glorious return of Lady Shar's pure, endless darkness. I had to act. I had to strangle that foul conspiracy while it was still in the cradle. We learned all we could - the artefact was the one thing the Absolutists feared. The one thing they desperately wanted to keep out of their enemies' grasp. I had to have it.
Player: You thought you could best the Absolute? The githyanki?
Viconia DeVir: To fight so many foes openly could prove unwise. Shar's children are better deployed as daggers in the shadows, not massed upon a battlefield. So let the others fight, while we wait. Once they are spent and bloodied from each other, we would slip in and take the prize. Alas, most of those I sent, perished. All but one - Shadowheart.
Narrator: *Viconia trails off, holding your gaze with a dark, hungry look. She has staked everything on acquiring the Astral Prism.*
Viconia DeVir: I felt Shadowheart's presence in your mind, and with it, the artefact. She succeeded in retrieving it, but then it is you who appeared, not her. Where is the artefact?
Player: Long gone. That thing was more trouble than it was worth.
Viconia DeVir: No, I think not. The artefact occupies you greatly, I felt it. Most curiously as well - like you hate it and need it. Millstone and life preserver. Humour me with a little negotiation. Perhaps we can find terms that will allow blades to remain sheathed.
Player: All right, you wish to negotiate? Make me an offer then.
Viconia DeVir: How about the artefact for your life? And perhaps even my support in the battles yet to come, against the Absolute?
Player: Not happening. Even if I wanted to give it to you, I can't. The artefact is bound to me. It will kill you.
Viconia DeVir: My interest is defeating the Absolute. It seems you're on that path already. I will not have it said that I am unreasonable. Shadowheart. Surrender her to me - she has much to answer for.
Player: Let me go, and I'll bring her to you.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Hail, friend. Fine day, isn't it? Forgive me - you're in no mood to talk about the weather. Your journey here was a hard one, no doubt.
 Is this your first time in Baldur's Gate?
Player: It's best to not ask where I conduct my... business. For your own safety.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Is that so? Enigmatic soul, aren't you? A word of advice then - you might not get as warm a welcome as in days gone by. Used to be you'd arrive knowing you'd a full belly and a warm bed waiting for you. Not any more. These days, there's barely enough to go around. Add the refugees on top and... well, folk aren't feeling too generous.
Player: Is there anything I can do to ease these people's burden?
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: I've been asking myself the same question. I wouldn't be the first to interfere. Some well-to-do's in the city donated enough to see the newcomers right for the time being. Only they didn't bother helping everyone else. Locals going without while strangers feast - it's stoked the fire, all right. Some Baldurians are kicking up a fuss round the front of the barn as we speak. If I wasn't wearing this uniform, I'd walk round there and teach them a lesson they'd never forget.
Player: The people of this city have grown selfish. They need reminding what true hardship is.
Nightwarden Minthara: We can be the reminder. Soft citizens make easy targets.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Too bloody right. They've gone soft behind those walls, forgotten what it's like to struggle, living hand-to-mouth. I say we march round there and slit a few bellies. Remind them how much worse things could be. What do you say? We need to march round the front, and kill every last one of them. Let's see them eat our food with their guts on the floor. What do you say?
Player: Let's soak the earth with entrails, kill and kill again!

Karlach: Something on your mind? Hey, soldier.

NodeContext: Projected voice
Morghal: Drugh no. The Twat-Soul caused a rockfall. Trapped tighter than a ring on a fat finger.

Player: I am Lae'zel - daughter of Gith, defender of Queen Vlaakith. And I am no slave.
Morghal: Well la-dee-damn-da. I'm empress of this dock, and when I say 'jump', you ask 'how high?'

Morghal: I'll be - you ain't shittin'. Felt the tingle. In that case, let's talk business. Your Twat-Soul friend Nere caused a rockfall. Trapped tighter than a hornet's arse.
Stone Guard Orgarth: Coupla gnome slaves stuck with him too, little bastards.

Arabella: Hey - I know you! You're -

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The creatures groan menacingly and prepare to lunge
Arabella: Twist'em up!
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Arabella casts her spell. Before the creatures can attack, vines rise from the ground and wrap around them, entangling them to her right
Astarion: It's you - our little idol thief from the druids' grove!
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Arabella turns away from the trapped creature, exhausted.
Arabella: Sorry. Knocks the wind right out of me.
Player: I'd be more impressed if you'd actually killed it.
Arabella: I don't know how. I'd kill 'em all if I could. I - I just want my mum and pops. We followed Zevlor out here. Then he - he - Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran. I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't.
Narrator: *You notice the girl shivering in fear and anger. She is not yet ready to hear the truth of her parents' fate.*
Player: Nature's magic only grows stronger with age, little one. Learn to control it now, while you still can.
Arabella: If I get strong enough, I won't have to run next time... Hmm. Okay. I promise to be really good with practising - but only if you look for my mum and pops. Deal?
Player: I'll find your parents - you can count on me.
Arabella: Thanks so much. I knew you'd help me again! The vines won't last forever. I don't - I don't s'pose I can stay with you?
NodeContext: Slightly unsure of herself.
Arabella: Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!
Player: I was just poking at the rancid dog-meat of your parents' corpses.
Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.
Player: Their bodies fester, pumped full enough of quack serums, swelling organs ready to burst.

Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Something called the Nightsong. Your notes were very interesting. Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: Because I am magical powerhouse. You need me, and you know it. It's simple - you need me. Don't pretend otherwise.
Balthazar: ...Fine. Your usefulness may outweigh your insolence - for now. There are much grander things at stake.
NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course. Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work... Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: You have resources to spare - give me something to aid my search.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell... ...Hmm. Misplaced, it seems. You will be capable enough without it.
Player: This sounds like your problem, not mine. Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do. I'll see what I can do.

Viconia DeVir: You may have evaded the Mapping of the Heart, but never mind - I can delve into your true intentions right now...
Narrator: *You feel the barest of presences caress your mind - she's reading your thoughts.*
Viconia DeVir: Ah, as I thought. Quite an adventure has brought you to this point - illithids, kidnapping, infection, the Hells, hunted by cultists and githyanki alike... and of course, the artefact. You have value. Quite an adventure has brought you to this point - illithids, kidnapping, infection, the Hells, hunted by cultists and githyanki alike... and of course, the artefact.
NodeContext: Ill-ih-thids
Player: I know I have value to my patron - but what you see in me I've no idea.
Viconia DeVir: Oh but I think you do - the Mapping unearthed much more than your heartform - I saw all your secrets. I felt Shadowheart's presence in your mind, and with it, the artefact. She succeeded in retrieving it, but then it is you who appeared, not her. Where is the artefact?
Player: Why do you even want it?
Viconia DeVir: I did not consent to questions. But I suppose you have undergone a great deal to reach this place, and anything I tell you cannot compromise me now - for you will either leave on my terms, or not at all... Whispers reached my ears from all corners - potential rivals of Lady Shar, all vying for the same prize. A new god, amassing the disaffected, the outcasts - those who should turn to us. This 'Absolute' is but an upstart; disturbing the natural order and threatening to impede the glorious return of Lady Shar's pure, endless darkness. I had to act. I had to strangle that foul conspiracy while it was still in the cradle. We learned all we could - the artefact was the one thing the Absolutists feared. The one thing they desperately wanted to keep out of their enemies' grasp. I had to have it.
Player: You thought you could best the Absolute? The githyanki?
Viconia DeVir: To fight so many foes openly could prove unwise. Shar's children are better deployed as daggers in the shadows, not massed upon a battlefield. So let the others fight, while we wait. Once they are spent and bloodied from each other, we would slip in and take the prize. Alas, most of those I sent, perished. All but one - Shadowheart.
Narrator: *Viconia trails off, holding your gaze with a dark, hungry look. She has staked everything on acquiring the Astral Prism.*
Viconia DeVir: I felt Shadowheart's presence in your mind, and with it, the artefact. She succeeded in retrieving it, but then it is you who appeared, not her. Where is the artefact?
Player: Long gone. That thing was more trouble than it was worth.
Viconia DeVir: No, I think not. The artefact occupies you greatly, I felt it. Most curiously as well - like you hate it and need it. Millstone and life preserver. Humour me with a little negotiation. Perhaps we can find terms that will allow blades to remain sheathed.
Player: As far as the artefact is concerned, there's nothing to discuss.
Viconia DeVir: Reconsider. Aid me, and you can count on my support against the Absolute. Reject me, and your journey ends here. How about the artefact for your life? And perhaps even my support in the battles yet to come, against the Absolute?
Player: The artefact alone can't save you. Best if we unite against our common enemy - the Absolute.
Viconia DeVir: My interest is defeating the Absolute. It seems you're on that path already. I will not have it said that I am unreasonable. Shadowheart. Surrender her to me - she has much to answer for.
Player: Let me go, and I'll bring her to you.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar. See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy. Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace. Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver. Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours. Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Darkness.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly. It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Shadowheart: A stinging truth - but a truth nonetheless.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being? If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain... We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The sisters aren't ready. They'll make me sick instead of curing me.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede. How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other. Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure? The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey. Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart. You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure. Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I sought purpose in the natural world - I see now that Shar is the only path. Show me how - I beg of you. I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be. Observe - then succeed me, into the succour of Shar.

Barth: You found it? I... I don't know what to say.
NodeContext: Gruff, edge of tears.
Barth: I know it's stupid. It's all I have of her, is all.
NodeContext: Gruff, edge of tears.
Barth: Kind of you, friend. Here's something for your troubles.
NodeContext: Snuffling.
Barth: My mum gave me that locket on her godsdamned deathbed. The boy took the thing. I know it.
Player: You mean this locket? How much is it worth to you?
Barth: How did you... all right, fine. I'll give you some coin for it.
Player: Thank you kindly.

Questioner Sumera: You were adored, Minthara. Brought up from the darkness, and into the Absolute's light.
Questioner Jasin: She cherished you. But it wasn't enough - you were distracted by your own desires.
Questioner Sumera: Bloodlust. Murder. Chaos.
Questioner Jasin: And most damning of all, an inability to follow orders.
Nightwarden Minthara: I obeyed to the best of my ability.
Questioner Sumera: And isn't that depressing?
Questioner Jasin: You are nothing.
Narrator: *The drow reaches out to you psychically, connecting with you for a moment. She is infected, like you, and her mind is disintegrating.*
Questioner Sumera: Come to observe, True Soul? She is a lesson - none can rise so high that they cannot fall again.
Player: I hope her punishment won't be too severe - she tried her best.
Questioner Sumera: We are erasing her.
Player: Stand aside. I'm taking charge here.
Questioner Sumera: Yes - your authority is great. We can learn, watching you break what little remains of her mind.
Questioner Jasin: Her mind is yours. Break it.
Player: Reach out for the drow's mind.
Narrator: *Immediately, your mind is swept into a greater vortex. A psionic storm with Minthara at its centre.*
GROUP_GLO_VoiceOfTheAbsolute: -CANNOT-
                   -hide-
-SUBMIT-
                   -embrace-

Narrator: *Her torturers are not dominating her - they are destroying her mental defences, and exposing her to the presence that claims to be the Absolute.*
Player: Push past the presence, towards the drow.
Narrator: *At your familiar touch, the presence withdraws. Still there, you sense, but letting you pass. Waiting.*
GROUP_GLO_VoiceOfTheAbsolute: -your-
                -ally/foe/PREY-

-my-
                -gift/offering/CLAIM-
Narrator: *Navigating the storm, you reach the nexus of her mind. It is a wound, bleeding raw emotion and shattered memories. But she senses your arrival.*
Nightwarden Minthara: So it is you who will end me. Make it swift, then. Anything to silence that thing - that voice.
Player: I have a plan - fake obedience, and the guards will leave without raising the alarm.
Nightwarden Minthara: I would prefer to make these bastards bleed, but I trust that you speak from caution rather than cowardice. I will put my faith in you, and pretend to be their slave.
Questioner Jasin: Is it done? I did not feel her mind break.
Player: Look at her. The True Soul Minthara you knew is gone.
Questioner Sumera: She does look a little... vacant, sister.
Questioner Jasin: No more anger, no more doubt. She is perfect. We ought to return to our posts, sister. There'll be plenty more prisoners to practice on.

Player: Not anymore.
Gerringothe Thorm: BUT... GOLD. GOLD. YOU... MUST PAY... NO. I PAY IT BACK!

Mol: Anyway. You want to talk? Talk.
Player: Why're you running all these schemes and swindles? Risky, you know.
Mol: We're saving up for a better hideout when we get to Baldur's Gate. Why, you planning on telling me stealing is wrong?
Player: Yes. You're taking advantage during bad times. There are words for folk like that.
Mol: So what? Should we be panicking like everyone else? We have a plan. We're the ones who'll end up on top in the Gate. Anything else? Anyway. You want to talk? Talk.
Player: Why're you running all these schemes and swindles? Risky, you know.
Mol: We're saving up for a better hideout when we get to Baldur's Gate. Why, you planning on telling me stealing is wrong?
Player: Yes. You're taking advantage during bad times. There are words for folk like that.

Player: Why're you running all these schemes and swindles? Risky, you know.
Mol: We're saving up for a better hideout when we get to Baldur's Gate. Why, you planning on telling me stealing is wrong?
Player: Not at all. You've got foresight - that'll help you to survive.
Mol: Foresight's the least of what we've got going, but thanks. Anyway. You want to talk? Talk.
Player: I'm shy a few of my belongings - one of your associates robbed me.
Mol: Maybe one of the kids picked up something of yours by mistake. I couldn't say. Might help if you pay the inspection fee. I could take a look. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: Mine. Now.
Mol: Threats, huh? The stones on you. Have it your way.
NodeContext: A beat before the line, thoughtful, surprised.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: |Snaps her fingers, holding out a hand, and a bag is handed to her. She gives it to the player.|
Mol: Here you go. Won't happen again. And to make sure none of the kids on the job outside mess with you, show them this:
Player: Copy the gesture.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: |PC mimics the hand gesture right.|
Mol: You got it. Now, we done here or what? Anyway. You want to talk? Talk.
Player: I didn't touch the idol. Don't know what happened to it.
Mol: You're a terrible liar. We had a deal.
Player: And now the deal's off. See you around.

Shadowheart: Damn thing... it has to open, surely. It has to do something.
Narrator: *Shadowheart's attention is consumed by a strange box that she turns over in her hands.* *The box is inscribed with glyphs similar to those used by the githyanki.*
Player: My kin's heirlooms should not be in your hands.
Narrator: *In an instant, Shadowheart hides the box from view.*
Shadowheart: It's nothing, trust me. Beautiful evening, isn't it?
NodeContext: Airy, deflecting.
Player: I suppose it is.
Shadowheart: You can really appreciate the darkness out here in the wilds. Not like in the city, where they keep lamps burning all hours. It's not natural.
NodeContext: A little philosophical (also keen to nudge conversation away from the gith artefact)
Player: I do like the dark. It's peaceful.
Shadowheart: Quite right. On that note, I think I'd like some time alone, if you don't mind. To meditate. We'll talk soon.
NodeContext:  Politely getting rid of the player.

Arabella: Hey - I know you! You're -
NodeContext: About to continue from 'Hey, I know you! You're - ' with a proper introduction, but is interrupted by shadow creature spawning from ground.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The creatures groan menacingly and prepare to lunge
Arabella: Twist'em up!
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Arabella casts her spell. Before the creatures can attack, vines rise from the ground and wrap around them, entangling them to her right
Astarion: It's you - our little idol thief from the druids' grove!
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Arabella turns away from the trapped creature, exhausted.
Arabella: Sorry. Knocks the wind right out of me.
Player: Normally tales of stolen artefacts are tragedies - I'm glad you've bucked that trend.
Arabella: Tragedies? Them's the sad ones, right? I hope not. 'Specially since mum and pops - After Zevlor - When he - Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran. I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't. Still can't find 'em - but I bet you can. You'll help me, I just know it!
Narrator: *You notice the girl shivering in fear and anger. She is not yet ready to hear the truth of her parents' fate.*
Player: Your parents are test-fodder stuffed full of needles, little orphan.
Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.
Player: I'm telling the truth: you don't want to find them.
Arabella: Then what... what is even left for me to do?
Player: Live, grow up, and make your path anew by my side.
Arabella: You're right. If I become strong, they will look on me with pride from beyond. All right. I'll go to the camp, like you said. Just... ...just don't leave me.

Player: I'm glad you made it too, it's one hell of a curse.
Alfira: It wasn't the curse that did us in. We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Ikaron was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.
 Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Which one was Ikaron again?
Alfira: Which...? He was on the quiet side, but had a heart of gold. Back in the grove, he'd kept an eye on the kids. Gods, that feels like a lifetime ago. Some of us fought back - or tried to. But it was hopeless. All I could do was run.
Player: What did the cultists do to the others?
Alfira: I don't know. It just... happened so quickly. How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: I take what I'm due and I don't look back.
Alfira: That sounds quite freeing - but I don't have that option, I'm afraid. You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there. If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I'll do everything in my power to save them - you have my most solemn vow.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: It is so good to see you again! I can't tell you how glad I am that you didn't enter the House without me.
Player: Who are you?
Narrator: *The figure shimmers brightly. Your words seem to have piqued her curiosity.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Who am I? It's my favourite question. I scream it into the dark while I sleep, and whisper it to my memories when I wake. I'm the thing that kills you, and the only reason you're alive. Made by a promise, undone by the truth. A handshake, a hug, the first beat of a newborn's heart. I am Hope. What little is left of her. A GUTTERING CANDLE IN A UNIVERSE OF NIGHT
Karlach: Raphael's driven her mad. Poor soul.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm not much of a friend to anyone anymore. But I could use a friend myself. Do you want a friend to guide you through this madhouse? Shhhtttt, I hear the jailor, it hears me. It'll call Raphael. Make every question count. Make some of them count twice.
Lae'zel: You must ask of the Orphic Hammer. Without it, the prince remains forever out of reach of my hungry weapon.
: NodeContext: urgent hushing and frantically getting out all of her words as quickly as possible. She's hushing the player, even though she was the one speaking
Player: I need to find the Orphic Hammer. Can you help?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Hope can help. The Hammer is here, in this House - it's...
Narrator: *You hear a sound like the rattle of a chain, and an agonising scream in your head as Hope flickers from view momentarily.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Shhhhttttt... Quiet... There it goes... Everyone here is mad - even you, especially me - and that makes them dangerous. But it also makes them stupid. I'll make you seem as ruined as the rest of the people here. A simple glamour to make you a terrible wretch.
NodeContext: very enthusiastic, casting a spell to disguise the player
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Now whisper your questions, little wretch. But really quiet, and very clever. Concentrate.
Player: Try really hard not to roar your words. Focus on speaking as quietly and calmly as possible.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Remember. Quiet as a mouse.
Player: What Hammer are you talking about?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: THE ONE THAT RAT-A-TATTED THE CHAINS IN PLACE AND BROKE THE FUTURE Discovered an ancient gith prince in need of a saviour? The Orphic Hammer is the perfect tool for breaking all infernal chains. In the Archive. Down the corridor, past the debtors. OH! The debtors. They won't like you. But I like you. I know I do, I think I do, I hope I do. I just need to ask one question, and I'll know for sure.
Player: No. I'm not telling you anything.

Zevlor: You're the one who knocked my jaw out of joint.
NodeContext: Player knocked Zevlor out to defuse an earlier confrontation - he's a bit aggrieved
Zevlor: And yet you walk in here like it's your domain. Typical drow arrogance. Lucky for you, you seem to have spooked Aradin and his trash into leaving. Raise your hand to one of us again, however, and every tiefling in this encampment will fall on you like a tide.
Player: Loose tongue, bruised jaw - perhaps they're related?
Zevlor: I'll survive a sore jaw. And you'll survive as long as you keep your hands to yourself. You helped us fight those goblins. Who are you?
Player: I'm [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53].
Zevlor: I'm Zevlor. It will be smart for both of us to make allies of enemies. Whatever your business here, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This latest attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: I won't be staying long - I just need to find a healer.
Zevlor: They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: I was there, you know. I'd hoped you'd had a happy ending.
Zevlor: We got out alive. That's what matters. And you did too, by the looks of things. We'll live to tell another tale, if we can just convince these druids not to turn us out on our backsides. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.

Narrator: *Behind the Watcher's gaze, a presence awakens. You are seen, you are known.* *Your infernal machinery seems to snap to attention, almost singing in recognition.*

He Who Was: The air stirs in trepidation - you have the ledger.
Player: Here - take it.
He Who Was: We have it - her lies, her guilt. Madeline reported her friends to a Dark Justiciar and fled when they were butchered. Well, she flees no more. I will be the conduit for Madeline's spirit. I will force her to face trial. And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: I'm here to make sure she sees justice.
He Who Was: There is no justice for traitors - only pain. Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.

Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Wyll: Not as if you can relate to the killing urge, can you? Hmph - I can taste the hypocrisy from here.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining. The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: My gorge rises at your sickening naivety.
Madeline: No - no that wasn't the worst of it. She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs. On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so. She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Stab yourself. Rip your stomach open. Feel the pain of your friends - only then will you be free. Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.

Player: What is this place?
Ptaris: It is my home, of course. Father raised me here. Taught me. Made me grow. I am Ptaris. And I am good. Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: Who was your father?
Ptaris: Havkelaag. He brought me from the shell. Raised me quickly. Taught me to be good. But he failed me. He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure. Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death. Tell me - are you a good person?
Player: I like to think so.
Ptaris: If you only think, then you do not know. The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?
Player: No one code can define goodness. It's impossible.
Ptaris: Only a bad person would say that. And that's what you are. I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head. You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like Vlaakith's, but he knows nothing of the Protocols.

Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Z'rell spoke of a relic - something called the Nightsong in your notes. They were very interesting. Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: I had Z'rell's permission - that good enough for you?
Balthazar: Z'rell exceeds her authority. But fine, I'll overlook your transgressions this time - there are much grander things at stake. The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course. Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work... Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: For jobs like this it's good form to provide your operatives some extra resources.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell... ...and he will come. My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Actually, I have your mother.
Balthazar: What the...? Give me back my mother, this instant!
Player: No, I think I'll keep her.

Player: You think a few shadows could beat me?
Alfira: ...Wait. No one's told you? We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Asharak was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right. Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Which one was Ikaron again?
Alfira: Which...? He was on the quiet side, but had a heart of gold. Back in the grove, he'd kept an eye on the kids. Gods, that feels like a lifetime ago. Some of us fought back - or tried to. But it was hopeless. All I could do was run.
Player: What did the cultists do to the others?
Alfira: I don't know. It just... happened so quickly. How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: Danger is my life - there is no greater thrill for me than the hunt.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then. You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there. If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: Don't worry, I'll find them.

Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark. You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance. Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her. I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things. I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54]) Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months. You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'. The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions. I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue. Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: That kind of indoctrination and time-forced nurture violates the natural order. It invalidates the whole experiment.
Havkelaag: I won't bother to argue with you. An arboreal shaman can't be expected to understand the rigorous protocols of theoretical research. My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: And what if your experiment fails?
Havkelaag: If the child remains evil after the experiment is concluded, it will be destroyed. Such is the fate of all used specimens. Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

Player: Here's the locket. It's all yours.
Barth: You found it? I... I don't know what to say.

Barth: I know it's stupid. It's all I have of her, is all.
NodeContext: Gruff, edge of tears.
Barth: Kind of you, friend. Here's something for your troubles.
NodeContext: Snuffling.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic. Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.
Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn. But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do... How is this possible...?
Player: I don't know.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know. I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them. Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected. I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help. I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from. That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: How did you come to study mind flayer parasites?
Halsin: A drow forced me to defend myself. Afterwards, I was able to study the parasite that slithered out of the corpse, see what drives these 'True Souls'. I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: What should I do?
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers. Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic. If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: You seem to know a lot about this. Will you come with me to Moonrise?
Halsin: I wish I could, but there's still work I've yet to finish - blood I've yet to spill. I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise. I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Kagha is dead. She was swayed by Shadow Druids. I had no choice.
Halsin: Kagha... This is my fault - I was her teacher. I will mourn her when I can. But there are other matters to attend to before that. Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural. Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.
 Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut. They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: I'll deal with this. You get to safety.
Halsin: There is no safety. Not while this rot festers. Once it is cut out - once the grove is secure - then I shall leave.
Player: Follow me, then. Your bear form may prove useful.
Halsin: Be warned - my presence could make things more difficult... I can only restrain my bear form so much. I won't be able to help but attack goblins. If I join you, we'll likely have to slaughter this entire place. You may want to use discretion when approaching the goblin leaders.
Player: Stay here.

Player: You've never seen another githyanki before?
Ptaris: I am not a githyanki. Do not call me that! I am Ptaris. And I am good. Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.

Ptaris: Everyone judges, and everyone must be judged. This is the only way to know if we are good enough. Father was not. He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure. Player: I fight, eat, drink, love, and hate with everything I have - that is all that matters.

NodeContext: Player intervened and stopped Zevlor and Aradin fighting. Zevlor is grateful and a little abashed.
Zevlor: The stories I was raised on don't equate drow with diplomacy - I'm glad to see they were baseless. I'm Zevlor. And you're...?

Zevlor: You'll find him in camp. What do you want with him?
Player: That is between the two of us.
Zevlor: You'll find him in the caves. But I warn you not to start trouble. There's already enough going. Whatever your business here, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This latest attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: I have no quarrel with druids.
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: If your people survived that, they'll survive anything.
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar. See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy. Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace. Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver. Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours. Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Loss.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly. It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Wyll: Hells. Only a monster would inflict misery and call it medicine.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being? If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure. We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The sisters aren't ready. They'll make me sick instead of curing me.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede. How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other. Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure? The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey. Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.

Lorroakan: Mark my words: the Nightsong is mine. With or without your help, she will ascend to her grand fate here, in this tower. You can get very rich along the way, or let someone else take what's rightfully yours. Choose wisely.

Zevlor: Now that's settled. Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him. Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor. And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down. You can tell my allegiance from a look?
Isobel: It's an aura. Or a lack of one, really. Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle. But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I'm glad you've remembered who needs whose help here.
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I need nothing from a Selûnite.
Isobel: But any others who travel with you may not agree. Do it for them at least - you will need all the help you can get out there.
Narrator: *Pain bursts from the wound on your hand. You see yourself kneeling in a dark hall, surrounded by initiates. A female voice preaches against Selûne and all she stands for. You nod, rapt.*
InternalNodeContext: Incurable wound imagery/memoriy fragment
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance. This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is. Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: I don't know what to make of it myself.
Isobel: I suppose Shar is nothing if not mysterious. I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I do, though I already have a Moonlantern. I already have a Moonlantern. I can safely travel the shadows.
Isobel: Well! If I'd have realised, I'd have spared the theatrics. In that case, you should be able to navigate a path straight to your target. That's good - very good. I wish you luck. The very best of it.
Player: Hold on - Marcus is a True Soul. He's here to kidnap you.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar. See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy. Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace. Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver. Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: What lesson are you teaching these sisters?
Malus Thorm: The crux of our worship. Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Loss.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly. It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Wyll: Hells. Only a monster would inflict misery and call it medicine.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being? If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure. We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede. How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other. Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure? The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey. Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart. You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure. Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I am but a fumbling squire before a master swordsman. Please, demonstrate so that I might learn. I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be. Observe - then succeed me, into the succour of Shar.

Zevlor: The Blade of Frontiers. An honour, no matter the circumstance. Have you spoken to Kagha?
Player: I want to discuss something else.
Zevlor: What is it?
Player: I'm looking for a man named Zorru.
Zevlor: You'll find him in camp. What do you want with him?
Player: That is between the two of us.
Zevlor: You'll find him in the caves. But I warn you not to start trouble. There's already enough going. Whatever your business here, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This latest attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Those goblins - have there been many attacks like that?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: Is there a place for tieflings anywhere?
Zevlor: Hah - a fair point. We can only hope the citizens of Baldur's Gate are more open-minded. But we can't get there with those beasts blocking our path. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Player: That's sad - but it doesn't mean the druids owe you sanctuary.
Zevlor: It seems you're of a mind with our hosts here. But their ritual will force you out, too. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't see me. You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place. Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I'm sorry. I've got my own problems.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: My dearest boy. The Hells have touched you. But you've come to me - just as Gortash said you would. Father and son, unstoppable generals. Together, we will usher in a new dawn. Have you come to behold the new dawn?

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: It is so good to see you again! I can't tell you how glad I am that you didn't enter the House without me.
Player: Who are you?
Narrator: *The figure shimmers brightly. Your words seem to have piqued her curiosity.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Who am I? It's my favourite question. I scream it into the dark while I sleep, and whisper it to my memories when I wake. I'm the thing that kills you, and the only reason you're alive. Made by a promise, undone by the truth. A handshake, a hug, the first beat of a newborn's heart. I am Hope. What little is left of her. A GUTTERING CANDLE IN A UNIVERSE OF NIGHT
Karlach: Raphael's driven her mad. Poor soul.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm not much of a friend to anyone anymore. But I could use a friend myself. Do you want a friend to guide you through this madhouse? Shhhtttt, I hear the jailor, it hears me. It'll call Raphael. Make every question count. Make some of them count twice.
Lae'zel: You must ask of the Orphic Hammer. Without it, the Prince of the Comet - and the githyanki people - remain forever chained.
: NodeContext: urgent hushing and frantically getting out all of her words as quickly as possible. She's hushing the player, even though she was the one speaking
Player: Who's your jailor?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: The many eyes. The stare of pain. The ray of death. Keep it away. Keep it away. Don't waste any more words, or we'll both be sorry. The House is home to many things. Most of them really want to kill you. I strongly suggest you try not to let that happen. Find your contract instead - save your soul!
Narrator: *You hear a sound like the rattle of a chain, and an agonising scream in your head as Hope flickers from view momentarily.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Shhhhttttt... Quiet... There it goes... Everyone here is mad - even you, especially me - and that makes them dangerous. But it also makes them stupid. I'll make you seem as ruined as the rest of the people here. A simple glamour to make you a terrible wretch.
NodeContext: very enthusiastic, casting a spell to disguise the player
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Now whisper your questions, little wretch. But really quiet, and very clever. Concentrate.
Player: Whisper as you would in the depths of a hunt. Focus on speaking as quietly and calmly as possible.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Remember. Quiet as a mouse.
Player: Where is Raphael?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: BEHIND YOU Skipping across the planes, spinning plates, making deals with dukes and devils. He's a busy man. A business-man. But not a man at all, of course. He'll be home soon, though, and you better find the Hammer before he arrives. Remember. Quiet as a mouse.
Player: I need to find the Orphic Hammer. Where is it?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Discovered an ancient gith prince in need of a saviour? The Orphic Hammer is the perfect tool for breaking all infernal chains. In the Archive. Down the corridor, past the debtors. OH! The debtors. They won't like you. But I like you. I know I do, I think I do, I hope I do. I just need to ask one question, and I'll know for sure.
Player: No. I'm not telling you anything.

Zethino: Violence erupts here - my home. My refuge in this city of stone and steel. Solace escapes me... Your eyes, stira. There is pain, endless and deep. But also devotion - blazing like the sun. You're in love, are you not?
Player: I do love someone - someone close to me, actually.
Zethino: You are wise to admit it. When it comes to love, vulnerability is armour. Truth, a sword. And trust, a shield. I pray you wield all three, stira. Bring the one you love to me. I will look into your hearts and see if your love is eternal. Or doomed eternally. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: What do you say, Shadowheart?
Shadowheart: Love, is it? I hadn't realised I'd bowled you over that much. Give it a try, then - impress me.
Zethino: Close your eyes, little ones. Be still as stone to earth. And remember to breathe.

Zethino: The sweetest loves dance lightly on the tongue. But now we must dig deeper. Into the most painful reaches of the spirit. Shame sits in the soul of all - to tame it, we must name it. Shadowheart - what is her deepest shame?
Player: She doesn't know who she is, or where she belongs.

Lorroakan: You have a job to do. So do it - quickly.
Player: You must be the wizard Lorroakan. I've heard a great deal about you.
Lorroakan: My - could it be? Gale of Waterdeep, here in my tower. I'm surprised you dare show your face after Mystra cast you on the scrap heap. Well don't stand on ceremony - out with it.
Player: I seek a certain rare tome - concerning Karsus.
Lorroakan: You're quite in luck, then - see Tolna downstairs. One such tome is amongst our rarest books. But enough of dusty history - I look to the future. You know I seek the Nightsong. Do you have it or not?
Player: What do you want with her?
Lorroakan: 'She'. Then you do know her. You've been to Shar's temple. To the Shadowfell. You've looked upon the Nightsong's face. Tell me - and choose your next words carefully - where is she now?
Player: Why do you want her so badly?
Lorroakan: I'm growing tired of this repartee, my friend. Let us cut to the chase. Beautiful, isn't it? Worth more than your life, too. I bought it from a Calishite warlock with very little of his soul left to him. It can bind a celestial to the wearer's service with a snap of the fingers. And this? This can keep her in place. Forever.
Player: A clever contraption. Let me guess: like Ketheric Thorm before you, you wish to become immortal.
Lorroakan: It didn't work out for poor Ketheric, did it? He was a fool. A desperate mercenary who whored out his soul to whichever god flattered him. I serve no god but that which stares back at me in the mirror. The Nightsong will be put to a grand purpose: equalising man and god. Whoever helps me attain that which I seek will be greatly rewarded.
Player: I've always dreamt of immortality. Your plan is quite clever.
Lorroakan: 'Clever' doesn't begin to describe it. What I seek is the greatest ambition possible: to defy the ultimate limitation, transcend the fate that awaits us all. When I succeed, I may look favourably upon you. If you are a friend along the way, that is. And this? This can keep her in place. Forever.
Player: I'm afraid the mighty Nightsong was no match for my magic. She's dead.

Brynna: You're a True Soul. You can't die. Please stay with us.
Andrick: I don't think he's conscious. Can you hear us, Ed?
Brynna: You! Not a step closer.
Narrator: *The mark glows, but you feel nothing in response. Your illithid power is beyond reach until you rest.*
Player: Freeze and hold up your hands.
Andrick: They might be a healer, Bry.
Brynna: They might be a bandit.
Edowin: Wait.
Narrator: *The injured man locks eyes with you. A familiar squirming churns in your head.*
Player: Hold his stare.
Narrator: *Your minds intertwine. You see his siblings - Andrick and Brynna. New recruits. Yours to shepherd.*
Edowin: Protect them. They are a True Soul. Mind them. They will - they - they...
NodeContext: Validated - he thought he sensed a likeminded individual, and was proven correct. Right on the verge of losing consciousness from his injuries. he dies after saying this.
Andrick: Edowin. Ed! Please!
NodeContext: Andrick drops his weapon and kneels beside Edowin.
Brynna: He's with the Absolute now.
NodeContext: Sad, mourning air
Brynna: You're... you're a True Soul. Edowin, our brother - he was chosen. Like you. Do you have orders for us? We were reporting to Edowin.
Player: Explain this Absolute to me.
Andrick: What...? Are you... are you testing us? The Absolute is our goddess. She's going to rip down the old world order, start a new one. Then we'll be the ones with the power - well, you will firstly, True Soul. You don't need me to explain that.
Brynna: And when the time comes, the True Souls - you - will rule.
Shadowheart: Please. Any supposed new god would have an uphill battle.
Brynna: Do you have orders for us? We were reporting to Edowin.
Player: The beast is dead. You should be on your way.
