Arabella: Hey - I know you! You're -
NodeContext: About to continue from 'Hey, I know you! You're - ' with a proper introduction, but is interrupted by shadow creature spawning from ground.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The creatures groan menacingly and prepare to lunge
Arabella: Twist'em up!
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Arabella casts her spell. Before the creatures can attack, vines rise from the ground and wrap around them, entangling them to her right
Gale: Wait, that's Arabella, is it not? Looks like she's got some new Weave up her sleeve.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Arabella turns away from the trapped creature, exhausted.
Arabella: Sorry. Knocks the wind right out of me.
Player: Normally tales of stolen artefacts are tragedies - I'm glad you've bucked that trend.
Arabella: Tragedies? Them's the sad ones, right? I hope not. 'Specially since mum and pops - After Zevlor - When he - Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran. I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't. Still can't find 'em - but I bet you can. You'll help me, I just know it!
Narrator: *You notice the girl shivering in fear and anger. She is not yet ready to hear the truth of her parents' fate.*
Player: Nature's magic only grows stronger with age, little one. Learn to control it now, while you still can.
Arabella: If I get strong enough, I won't have to run next time... Hmm. Okay. I promise to be really good with practising - but only if you look for my mum and pops. Deal?
Player: I'll think about it. My hands are full with these cultists.
Arabella: Fine. Whatever. I don't need you - I'll find them myself!
Player: You're going to get yourself killed. I'll find them, all right?
Arabella: Thanks so much. I knew you'd help me again! The vines won't last forever. I don't - I don't s'pose I can stay with you?
NodeContext: Slightly unsure of herself.
Arabella: Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!
Player: I was just poking at the rancid dog-meat of your parents' corpses.
Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.
Player: And are you tough enough?
Arabella: I'll prove it. Let me help in the camp, til you bring mom and pops back to me. Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!
Player: Suppress your delight in her parents' death. Offer her shelter.

Narrator: *Hollow-eyed faces stare out of the cells. Some meet your eyes, but most look away. There's an almost physical stink of decay and neglect.*
Sebastian: Please... what are you?
Player: Busy, that's what I am.
Sebastian: He'll find you, you know. And he won't kill you. He won't ever let you die.
Narrator: *Under the grime, you can see how pale he is. You can see the hunger in his eyes - in all of their eyes. Each one is an emaciated, starving vampire spawn.* *More than that, you can see that each prisoner is marked with a scar - the same as one of the runes from Astarion's back.*
Player: How did this happen to you?
Sebastian: Then it gets so dark. I woke up here. Like this.
Player: I'm going to help you. I'm going to kill Cazador.
Sebastian: You can't. It's not possible.
Player: I'll find a way.
Sebastian: And then? What happens to us? But even if you can kill him - what then? What happens to us?
Player: I have no intention of freeing a bunch of ravenous spawn.

Abdirak: Greetings, child. I've met few aside from goblins here.
NodeContext: Player is one of the few non-goblins he's met in this place. Welcomes another for conversation and discussion but there should be something vaguely threatening about him. Charismatic, sexy, and creepy all in one.
Player: InternalNodeContext: A player with the CLERIC or PALADIN tag will have this flag set alreay before starting the dialog, so they bypass the passive check
Abdirak: Ah, are you also here to assist with the prisoner?
Player: I talked with the torturers. Amateurs.
Abdirak: Quite right. I was invited to teach them. I live for pain and its intricacies, you see. But alas, they insist on being so primitive. Pain without purpose is a terrible thing, wouldn't you agree?
Player: I often feel I like raw pain too much. It scares me.
Abdirak: Forgive me, but that look in your eyes - something terrible has happened to you.
Player: Clever man. How did you know?
Abdirak: Because I see those same eyes when I look in the mirror, dear one. We've all suffered in these dark times. It is little wonder you bear scars of pain and anguish. Please let me alleviate this pain.
Player: And how would you do that?
Abdirak: As the Maiden of Pain, the goddess Loviatar, teaches us... ...through penance - administered by my skilled hand. My work can grant peace and serenity - the likes of which few experience. It will be worth it - I promise.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: He gestures to the table, where a selection of weapons lays ready. The priest should look very sincere in this scene. He genuinely
thinks he's helping you.
thinks he's helping you.
Gale: Your hide, your choice. Not quite my cup of tea though.
Player: Prepare for the coming pain.
Abdirak: Oh, I have something exquisite in mind. Both Loviatar and I are interested in how you handle pain, dear one.

Ptaris: You - you don't look like them. You look like me. Who are you?
Player: A githyanki? What are you doing down here?
Ptaris: I am not a githyanki. Do not call me that! I am Ptaris. And I am good. Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: Don't worry - I'm not here to judge.
Ptaris: Everyone judges, and everyone must be judged. This is the only way to know if we are good enough. Father was not. He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure. Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death. Tell me - are you a good person?
Player: I fight, eat, drink, love, and hate with everything I have - that is all that matters.
Ptaris: Such an empty and  meaningless life. The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?
Player: The code of Bahamut. His guidance leads me in all things.
Ptaris: Do you really believe that? You are unfit to say his name. I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head. You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like his kin's, but their ways are foreign.
Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.
NodeContext: Like this is the onyl reasonable conclusion
Player: You would have been destroyed if not for me. I saved you.
Ptaris: You were trying to save me? I - I don't understand. Father saved me. I was a nasty, evil thing, but his treatments made me good. I - I'm cured.

Withers: Ah, another. Thy name has been recorded. I shall be here in thy camp, for whenever thou hast need of my services.
Player: Not to be rude, but what are you?
Withers: There are many answers to that question. None are important.
Player: Skeletons aren't supposed to be able to talk.
Withers: Correct.
Player: Are you going to explain further?
Withers: No. No.
Player: You were sorting something before. What were you doing? Impressive. Are there other ways you can help us?
Withers: Should thou or any of thy compatriots perish, I will cleave soul to body once more.
Player: That's incredibly powerful magic. Why is it so easy for you?
Withers: Because it is my calling. There is little else to explain.
Player: I could use those resurrection services right now.
Withers: Then thou must return with the proper payment.

Withers: This is the price of balance. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: Actually, there's something else I need from you.
Withers: Dost thou require a resurrection?
Player: I would like to collect one of my fallen companions.
Withers: The fallen will rise when they are summoned. But thou must first make space for them amongst the living. Dost thou require a resurrection?

Zevlor: You acted quickly. I'm just sorry I didn't get there first. Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him. Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor. And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.
Player: Please - it's just Wyll.
Zevlor: Well met, by whatever name. Though I'm afraid that's all the welcome we can give you. Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: I won't be staying long - I just need to find a healer.
Zevlor: They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Karlach: Gods, these are those tiefs? Their whole city was dragged into Avernus for a while. Zariel was delighted. When they made it back out, I'd hoped they got their happy ending.
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: If your people survived that, they'll survive anything.
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: I was there, you know. I'd hoped you'd had a happy ending.
Zevlor: We got out alive. That's what matters. And you did too, by the looks of things. We'll live to tell another tale, if we can just convince these druids not to turn us out on our backsides. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me. You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place. Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I have my own temporal concerns. I need a healer. Enough about the ritual. I have my own problems.

Esther the expeditioner: S_GLO_Expeditioner_5f4048ba-72ef-43c2-9528-1c9a12f3f82f
Narrator: *A githyanki youth, and a familiar one at that. Can it be that this is the one who hatched from the egg you took from the crèche?*
Player: I'm [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53]. Who are you?
Ptaris: I am Ptaris. And I am good. Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: So you killed them?
Ptaris: It is not my fault they died. I was only upholding father's code. Even he was not strong enough to follow it. He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure. Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death. Tell me - are you a good person?
Player: I like to think so.
Ptaris: If you only think, then you do not know. The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?
Player: I live by my own code, though not the one you speak of.
Ptaris: Then your code is flawed. Your actions cannot be defended. I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head. You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like Vlaakith's, but he knows nothing of the Protocols.
Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.
NodeContext: Like this is the onyl reasonable conclusion
Player: I thought I was saving you. I had no idea what they were planning. You would have been destroyed if not for me. I saved you.
Ptaris: You were trying to save me? I - I don't understand. Father saved me. I was a nasty, evil thing, but his treatments made me good. I - I'm cured.

Barth: Thanks to you, that kid has my locket. My mum gave that to me on her deathbed. Thanks to you, that kid has my mum's locket and I got a beating.
 Got nothing to say to you. You got nothing I want.

Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create. General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall. You and all the rest have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make. You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: I wield the divine. I can use it to assist you, or send you screaming to the Fugue Plane. Your choice. You're hiding from shadows - literally. Don't make threats you can't back up.
Balthazar: ...Fine. I'll forgive your transgressions this time - there are much grander things at stake.
NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course. Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: You have resources to spare - give me something to aid my search.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell... ...and he will come. My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Actually, I have your mother.
Balthazar: What the...? Give me back my mother, this instant!
Player: No, I think I'll keep her.

Alfira: First cultists nearly murder us, and now we have a traitor on the inside? Can't we trust anyone?
NodeContext: frustrated and tired of being scared
Player: Cultists? What happened?
Alfira: Stars, you hadn't heard?
 We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Someone told them to rot in the Nine Hells, that we weren't going anywhere. Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Which one was Asharak again?
Alfira: Which...? Back in the grove, he ran drills with the kids. Wooden swords and the like. That seems like a lifetime ago now. Rolan, of all people, saved us. He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: You're lucky to be alive.
Alfira: I don't feel lucky. I feel... I feel like I'm at the end of my rope. How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: It helps to remember what is at stake - I fight for nature, for balance. I fight for life itself.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then. You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there. If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: Don't worry, I'll find them.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The brewer drags itself to a bar counter, on which are two full mugs.
Thisobald Thorm: Drink, gulp it down, wet your whistle. Tell your story.

Thisobald Thorm: Son of Thorm. Sot of Sword Coast. Go on. Cheers, bottoms up, down the hatch.
Lae'zel: Hells. The curse has twisted this man beyond measure...
Player: Pick up the tankard.

Player: AGAIN! DRINK! Do as he says. Drink.

Thisobald Thorm: No more blah, bland, banal. Give me blood. Or I take it.
Player: I ripped one head from an ettin and force-fed it to the other.
Thisobald Thorm: Its eyes were not bigger than its belly, then? Hah! Delightful. A grisly tale with a frothing ale. Ask, question, make your query. And drink once more.

Lorroakan: Mark my words: the Nightsong is mine. With or without your help, she will ascend to her grand fate here, in this tower. You can get very rich along the way, or let someone else take what's rightfully yours. Choose wisely.
Player: You must be the wizard Lorroakan. I've heard a great deal about you.
Lorroakan: My - could it be? Gale of Waterdeep, here in my tower. I'm surprised you dare show your face after Mystra cast you on the scrap heap. Well don't stand on ceremony - out with it.
Player: I seek a certain rare tome - concerning Karsus.
Lorroakan: You're quite in luck, then - see Tolna downstairs. One such tome is amongst our rarest books. But enough of dusty history - I look to the future. You know I seek the Nightsong. Do you have it or not?
Player: What do you want with her?
Lorroakan: 'She'. Then you do know her. You've been to Shar's temple. To the Shadowfell. You've looked upon the Nightsong's face. Tell me - and choose your next words carefully - where is she now?
Player: Why do you want her so badly?
Lorroakan: I'm growing tired of this repartee, my friend. Let us cut to the chase. Beautiful, isn't it? Worth more than your life, too. I bought it from a Calishite warlock with very little of his soul left to him. It can bind a celestial to the wearer's service with a snap of the fingers. And this? This can keep her in place. Forever.
Player: I know where she is. I might even be willing to tell you.
Gale: You'd give up her location, just like that? You're not actually considering betraying her, are you...?
Nightwarden Minthara: Surrendering a powerful ally to this preening wizard does not seem wise.
Halsin: You broke Dame Aylin's shackles once before. Do not help this one to forge new ones for her.
Lorroakan: Good. Then you'll have no trouble fulfilling the contract to bring the Nightsong here.
Player: Why do you want her so badly?
Lorroakan: I'm growing tired of this repartee, my friend. Let us cut to the chase. Beautiful, isn't it? Worth more than your life, too. I bought it from a Calishite warlock with very little of his soul left to him. It can bind a celestial to the wearer's service with a snap of the fingers. And this? This can keep her in place. Forever.
Player: Binding the Nightsong forever... How unoriginal. Need I recite the tale of Ketheric Thorm? A clever contraption. Let me guess: like Ketheric Thorm before you, you wish to become immortal.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic. Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.
Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn. But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do... How is this possible...?
Player: I don't know.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know. I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them. Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected. I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help. I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from. That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: How did you come to study mind flayer parasites?
Halsin: A drow forced me to defend myself. Afterwards, I was able to study the parasite that slithered out of the corpse, see what drives these 'True Souls'. I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: Sympathies won't help me to survive.
Halsin: Patience. I can't just snap my fingers... but I know where the solution almost certainly lies. I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers. Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic. If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: Altered parasites? A cure at Moonrise Towers, maybe? Sounds like guesswork at best.
Halsin: I'm as certain as I can be. If you have a better alternative, I won't stop you. I can't stop you, in fact. Which brings me to my next problem... I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise. I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Look around you - there's no order anymore. Only chaos.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural. Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.
 Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut. They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: You are aware you're asking me to kill a drow?
Halsin: You drow relish turning on your own, if there's something to be gained. Don't pretend otherwise.
Player: Not all drow are as you say.
Halsin: Unfair of me, perhaps, but I've had few encounters with drow to make me think otherwise. Perhaps you can enlighten me.
Player: I'll deal with this. You get to safety.
Halsin: There is no safety. Not while this rot festers. Once it is cut out - once the grove is secure - then I shall leave.
Player: All right. Wait here until it's done.
Halsin: May Silvanus guide your hand. Focus on the leaders - that's all it will take to restore the balance here.

Arabella: Hey - I know you! You're -
NodeContext: About to continue from 'Hey, I know you! You're - ' with a proper introduction, but is interrupted by shadow creature spawning from ground.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The creatures groan menacingly and prepare to lunge

Wyll: Is that... the kid Kagha went after? Seems she's learned a new trick.

I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't. Still can't find 'em - but I bet you can. You'll help me, I just know it!
Narrator: *You notice the girl shivering in fear and anger. She is not yet ready to hear the truth of her parents' fate.*

Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.

Arabella: I'll prove it. Let me help in the camp, til you bring mom and pops back to me. Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!
Player: I was just poking at the rancid dog-meat of your parents' corpses.
Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.

Abdirak: Greetings, child. I've met few aside from goblins here.
NodeContext: Player is one of the few non-goblins he's met in this place. Welcomes another for conversation and discussion but there should be something vaguely threatening about him. Charismatic, sexy, and creepy all in one.
Player: InternalNodeContext: A player with the CLERIC or PALADIN tag will have this flag set alreay before starting the dialog, so they bypass the passive check
Narrator: *You recognise the scourge - this man is a follower of Loviatar, goddess of pain.*
Abdirak: Ah, are you also here to assist with the prisoner?
Player: You mean the one they are torturing?
Abdirak: Please. The things they are doing to that man... so crude and primitive. I was invited to to teach them. I live for pain and its intricacies, you see, but alas... Pain without purpose is a terrible thing, wouldn't you agree?
Player: What's a follower of the Maiden of Pain doing here?
Abdirak: Ah, you are familiar with the Scourge Mistress? Good. I am simply spreading her message, friend. I worship her through pain - usually my own. But I have a skilled hand when it comes to its infliction. Care to expand your horizons? It will be worth it - you have my word.
Wyll: I wouldn't let his 'skilled hand' anywhere near me.
Player: All right, why not?
Abdirak: Oh, I have something exquisite in mind. Both Loviatar and I are interested in how you handle pain, dear one.

Angry Mar'hyah: Woof!
Player: I beg your pardon?
Angry Mar'hyah: Ah. You speak. Which means you're not a dog. So what the hell are you doing in my kennels? You're not a dog. So what the hell are you doing in my kennels?
Player: Woof.
Angry Mar'hyah: Oh gods. Unless you want me to shove you in one of these cages, stop barking and start speaking.
Player: Sorry.
Angry Mar'hyah: It's fine. I have a very robust sense of humour. What do you want? You're not a dog. So what the hell are you doing in my kennels?
Player: Woof.
Angry Mar'hyah: Oh gods. Unless you want me to shove you in one of these cages, stop barking and start speaking.

Player: Is this dog one of yours?
Oyster Boy Dringo: Scratch! It's good to see you boy.
Angry Mar'hyah: Shut up, Dringo. And get back to work! And you've been slacking as well, Scratch m'boy. This dog is property of Sword Coast Couriers. I'll take him off your hands now.
Player: He is not 'property,' he is Scratch. Don't you dare threaten him.
Angry Mar'hyah: I can do whatever I please - he's my dog. Now get out - this is a private yard.
Player: This noble beast has tasted true freedom - he will never be brought to heel again.
Angry Mar'hyah: I'm not surprised. Gomwick always indulged him. And he's got a spark in his eye I don't like - looks lively. Take the useless mutt if you're so inclined. I'll have nothing more to do with him.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar. See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy. Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace. Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver. Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: What lesson are you teaching these sisters?
Malus Thorm: The crux of our worship. Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Darkness.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly. It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being? If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain... We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede. How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Practice - that's how I got good with a blade. They should spar each other. Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure? The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey. Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart. You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure. Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be. Observe - then succeed me, into the succour of Shar.

Esther the expeditioner: S_GLO_Expeditioner_5f4048ba-72ef-43c2-9528-1c9a12f3f82f
Narrator: *A githyanki youth, and a familiar one at that. Can it be that this is the one who hatched from the egg you took from the crèche?*
Player: I'm [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53]. Who are you?
Ptaris: I am Ptaris. And I am good. Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: So you killed them?
Ptaris: It is not my fault they died. I was only upholding father's code. Even he was not strong enough to follow it. He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure. Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death. Tell me - are you a good person?
Player: I like to think so.
Ptaris: If you only think, then you do not know. The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?
Player: The Ptarian code? Then you follow the teachings of Bahamut?
Ptaris: The purest of your rulers. But you are nothing like him. You are tainted. I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head. You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like his kin's, but their ways are foreign.
Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.
NodeContext: Like this is the onyl reasonable conclusion
Player: I never should have saved you. But I'm happy to rectify my mistake. You would have been destroyed if not for me. I saved you.
Ptaris: You were trying to save me? I - I don't understand. Father saved me. I was a nasty, evil thing, but his treatments made me good. I - I'm cured.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic. Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.
Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn. But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do... How is this possible...?
Player: I think this artefact has something to do with it.
Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world. You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know. I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them. Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected. I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help. I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from. That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: You learned all this from your studies?
Halsin: Indeed. After we dealt with the drow that ambushed us, Nettie and I were able to inspect the corpse - and the creature that slithered out of it. I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: What should I do?
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers. Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic. If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: Altered parasites? A cure at Moonrise Towers, maybe? Sounds like guesswork at best.
Halsin: I'm as certain as I can be. If you have a better alternative, I won't stop you. I can't stop you, in fact. Which brings me to my next problem... I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise. I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Kagha is dead. She was swayed by Shadow Druids. I had no choice.
Halsin: Kagha... This is my fault - I was her teacher. I will mourn her when I can. But there are other matters to attend to before that. Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural. Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.
 Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut. They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: Having a shapeshifting bear-druid at my side might make things easier. Follow me, then. Your bear form may prove useful.
Halsin: Be warned - my presence could make things more difficult... I can only restrain my bear form so much. I won't be able to help but attack goblins. If I join you, we'll likely have to slaughter this entire place. You may want to use discretion when approaching the goblin leaders.
Player: Stay here.

He Who Was: The air stirs in trepidation - you have the ledger.
Player: Here - take it.
He Who Was: We have it - her lies, her guilt. Madeline reported her friends to a Dark Justiciar and fled when they were butchered. Well, she flees no more. I will be the conduit for Madeline's spirit. I will force her to face trial. And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: I'm here to make sure she sees justice.
He Who Was: There is no justice for traitors - only pain. Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining. The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: If it was drunk complaining, why did you report them?
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar said to report everythin', big or small. She ain't the type you say no to. She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs. On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so. She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.
Madeline: Like... this?
NodeContext: Madeline draws a blade from behind her and holds it in front of her stomach, blade pointed towards her stomach. She is utterly terrified (pose like seppuku)
Player: Prove you're sorry. Do it for Ben and Marc.
Madeline: Ah! I'm sorry.
NodeContext: Ah! is a noise of pain as she stabs herself in the stomach and then pulls out the knife. 'I'm sorry' is said in clear pain.
Madeline: Argh. I'm so sorry.
NodeContext: stabs herself again on 'Argh', noise of pain. I'm so so sorry is half crying as she's in agony.
Player: Did I say stop? Drive the knife in deeper.

Zevlor: You're the one who knocked my jaw out of joint.
NodeContext: Player knocked Zevlor out to defuse an earlier confrontation - he's a bit aggrieved
Zevlor: And yet you walk in here like it's your domain. Typical drow arrogance. Lucky for you, you seem to have spooked Aradin and his trash into leaving. Raise your hand to one of us again, however, and every tiefling in this encampment will fall on you like a tide.
Player: Loose tongue, bruised jaw - perhaps they're related?
Zevlor: I'll survive a sore jaw. And you'll survive as long as you keep your hands to yourself. You helped us fight those goblins. Who are you?

Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Player: You made it back from Avernus. Surely you can survive anything?
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.

Viconia DeVir: They already heard how you disgraced yourself before Lady Shar. How she marked you as the enemy. But it is quite another thing for them to see it for themselves. I am very glad you decided to return. A cautionary tale such as yours will be studied by Lady Shar's initiates for years to come. Always a pleasure to see old acquaintances. But you would be wise to not interfere in this matter. No matter. You are here now, to face the Dark Lady's judgement, before a gathering of your peers. Give the artefact, and perhaps we will be merciful.
Shadowheart: No. I already faced Lady Shar. I passed her trials, I wielded her spear, and now I am her mortal voice. I have been embraced by her in ways you could only dream of.
Viconia DeVir: Nonsense. Ravings. You've strayed, girl - you've failed Lady Shar's mission and allowed ambition to rot your mind.
Shadowheart: Tell her. Tell them all. Tell them how the Nightsinger has blessed me.
Player: Wait. Before we go any further, tell me what this is about. Why do you even want the artefact?
Viconia DeVir: I did not consent to questions. But I suppose you have undergone a great deal to reach this place, and anything I tell you cannot compromise me now - for you will either leave on my terms, or not at all... Whispers reached my ears from all corners - potential rivals of Lady Shar, all vying for the same prize. A new god, amassing the disaffected, the outcasts - those who should turn to us. This 'Absolute' is but an upstart; disturbing the natural order and threatening to impede the glorious return of Lady Shar's pure, endless darkness. I had to act. I had to strangle that foul conspiracy while it was still in the cradle. We learned all we could - the artefact was the one thing the Absolutists feared. The one thing they desperately wanted to keep out of their enemies' grasp. I had to have it.
Player: Shar bid you to do all of this?
Viconia DeVir: Lady Shar's concerns lie elsewhere - with another. But she is a goddess... she can afford to ignore that which does not threaten her. I must keep her faith alive in mortal hearts. I must defend her ways, lead her children, stop all threats. Even if I must go against her wishes, I will prove myself her most loyal servant.
Shadowheart: You think you know better than the Dark Lady? No wonder she sent me to this place of your poison. Tell them what you witnessed. Tell them how Lady Shar favours me. Tell her. Tell them all. Tell them how the Nightsinger has blessed me.
Player: I saw her walk through a shadow curse, where others feared to venture. Shar favours her. I saw her walk through a shadow curse, where others feared to venture. Shar favours her.
Justiciar Crusader Nightmist: A true Sharran like you must be on the right side.
NodeContext: Supportive, swayed by the player's argument
Justiciar Crusader Nightmist: I shall stand with Shadowheart.
NodeContext: Swearing fealty (having just changed sides to support the player)
Viconia DeVir: So be it. A traitor's end awaits you all. These are the desperate lies of trapped vermin, nothing more. You are deluded, girl.
NodeContext: First part (up to 'awaits you all') addressed to Sharrans who have abandoned her. Middle (up to 'nothing more' addressed to her remaining supporters. Last part directed at shadowheart.
Shadowheart: I'm not here to convince you, Mother. You are already disgraced in Lady Shar's eyes. I merely wish to give the others a chance to repent, before they are dragged down with you.
Narrator: *A coup attempt. Shadowheart will need all the help she can get if she's to win over the remaining diehards from Viconia's ranks.*
Player: Do nothing.
Shadowheart: Viconia would have you hide down here, oblivious to the true danger - the Absolute must be stopped, and only I can lead you. Lady Shar has decreed it!
Viconia DeVir: The Absolute will be dealt with. As soon as I prise the artefact from your cold fingers. Enough talk, girl. The sooner we finish this, the sooner your blood can be sluiced off Lady Shar's sacred Grotto.
Player: Give Shadowheart a chance to sway more of Viconia's followers.
Shadowheart: Enough speeches - the odds are already in my favour. Do you think the Dark Lady would want you to die for a lost cause? Or show some cunning and live another day?

NodeContext: Player is one of the few non-goblins he's met in this place. Welcomes another for conversation and discussion but there should be something vaguely threatening about him. Charismatic, sexy, and creepy all in one.
Player: InternalNodeContext: A player with the CLERIC or PALADIN tag will have this flag set alreay before starting the dialog, so they bypass the passive check

Player: I talked with the torturers. Amateurs.
Abdirak: Quite right. I was invited to teach them. I live for pain and its intricacies, you see. But alas, they insist on being so primitive. Pain without purpose is a terrible thing, wouldn't you agree?
Player: As long as the story ends in death, it's all the same to me.
Abdirak: Forgive me, but that look in your eyes - something terrible has happened to you.

Abdirak: As the Maiden of Pain, the goddess Loviatar, teaches us... ...through penance - administered by my skilled hand. My work can grant peace and serenity - the likes of which few experience. It will be worth it - I promise.

thinks he's helping you.

Player: So you killed them?
Ptaris: It is not my fault they died. I was only upholding father's code. Even he was not strong enough to follow it. He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure. Player: I try to be, but sometimes my magic has other ideas.
Ptaris: There is no 'try'. You are either good or you are not. The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?

Ptaris: Yet you have killed, many times. It is engraved on your memories. You are a hypocrite. I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head. You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.

Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: It is so good to see you again! I can't tell you how glad I am that you didn't enter the House without me.

A GUTTERING CANDLE IN A UNIVERSE OF NIGHT

Zevlor: You're the one who knocked my jaw out of joint.
NodeContext: Player knocked Zevlor out to defuse an earlier confrontation - he's a bit aggrieved
Zevlor: And yet you walk in here like it's your domain. Typical drow arrogance. Lucky for you, you seem to have spooked Aradin and his trash into leaving. Raise your hand to one of us again, however, and every tiefling in this encampment will fall on you like a tide.
Player: Loose tongue, bruised jaw - perhaps they're related?
Zevlor: I'll survive a sore jaw. And you'll survive as long as you keep your hands to yourself. You helped us fight those goblins. Who are you?
Player: Just passing through.
Zevlor: Right. Best not to stop here. Whatever your business here, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This latest attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Why are they forcing you out?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: Let me guess: Your old neighbours called you 'devilkin' and acted like they never knew you.
Zevlor: How easily such a nasty word slips through the mouth of someone you thought you knew. We thought we'd found sanctuary here, but the druids have determined to turn us out. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.

Player: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?
Zevlor: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't see me. You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place. Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.

Narrator: *Behind the Watcher's gaze, a presence awakens. You are seen, you are known.* *Your infernal machinery seems to snap to attention, almost singing in recognition.*

GROUP_SteelWatchers: You are marked for special treatment. Not simply an enemy of the people, but an enemy of the Absolute. Come quietly, or die.

GROUP_SteelWatchers: Stand down, villain. In the name of the Steel Watch. Aggressive action will not be tolerated in the presence of the patriars of this proud city.

GROUP_SteelWatchers: The Steel Watch appreciate your cooperation, citizen.
NodeContext: Gets new command after starting to engage. Gortash sends a remote command to let the player through.
Lord Enver Gortash: Dearest patriars, but a moment. I must greet a most honoured guest.
NodeContext: Magninamously and a bir formal, but still in the style of a politician where you can't tell if he's being sarcastic
Lord Enver Gortash: Crawling back from their bloody disgrace - it's my favourite assassin! Gods, you're a sight for sore eyes. Orin told me she made a fool of you, but I should've known you wouldn't go down that easy.
Player: I have no clue what you're talking about - my memories are blighted.
Lord Enver Gortash: Then she didn't lie - the past is lost to you. Let me clear up some mysteries, then. We share so much history. You and I initiated this plot. We discussed in depth the failures of our predecessors and how to avoid them. We understood that if we were to unite, no one could stand in the way of the Dead Three. So unite we did. First we obtained the crown; then we enslaved the brain. From there, it was but a small step to the most successful religious hoax ever perpetrated.
Player: What was my role in this plan?
Lord Enver Gortash: In Bhaal's name, you set your bloody daggers to cause panic in the streets, killing in the Absolute's name. You would have carried out that part of the plan, had Orin not ruined your hard work. Next, the threat of the Absolute's monstrous armies formed by Myrkul's general, Ketheric Thorm. In such circumstances, people crave strong leaders. Leaders that bring law, order, and protection. Leaders like me, Bane's unyielding hand, author of justice. You are soon to witness the people of Baldur's Gate granting me complete power over them. All out of fear of the Absolute. Next, I - we - will declare curfew and begin infecting the masses. Our subjects will hear the voice of their Absolute god. The faithful will do anything in the name of their god.
Player: You make me sick.
Lord Enver Gortash: Yes, yes, I'm sure I do. Now come, be witness as I make history as the first Archduke of Baldur's Gate.
Player: I'd rather juice my own eyes.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar. See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy. Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace. Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver. Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: What wrong has this man done to deserve such torture?
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture. Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly. It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Wyll: Hells. Only a monster would inflict misery and call it medicine.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being? If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain... We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede. How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Practice - that's how I got good with a blade. They should spar each other. Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure? The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey. Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart. You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure. Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I am not worthy! Please, show me how a master works - I would be honoured. I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be. Observe - then succeed me, into the succour of Shar.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down. This Sharran exposed a traitor in your midst.
Isobel: Fair. I admit, Marcus waltzing around the place undetected bodes rather ill for our defences, doesn't it? Then again, the best defence is a good offence. Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle. But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I won't be spoken to like that by a Selûnite.
Isobel: We've both got a bitter pill to swallow. When this is all over, we can spit it back out. You'll be needing the protection spell, I presume? Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: Nod. Better to humour her than make an enemy of all in this place. Lady Shar will understand.
Isobel: Refreshingly pragmatic of you. I sense Shar has offered some amount of protection to you already, but... well, no harm in extra precaution - even from a Selûnite.
Narrator: *Pain bursts from the wound on your hand. You see yourself kneeling in a dark hall, surrounded by initiates. A female voice preaches against Selûne and all she stands for. You nod, rapt.*
InternalNodeContext: Incurable wound imagery/memoriy fragment
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance. This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is. Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: I don't know what to make of it myself.
Isobel: I suppose Shar is nothing if not mysterious. I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I do, though I already have a Moonlantern. I already have a Moonlantern. I can safely travel the shadows.
Isobel: Well! Now you have two. Just in case. I wish you luck. The very best of it.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face. Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Enlighten me. Fine, consider your merits acknowledged. Care to enlighten me as to what's going on?
Balthazar: There is a relic here. One which General Thorm desires. No - needs. I will retrieve it for him... ...and you will help me. Ignorant you may be, you've shown some prowess in scouting and combat by making it this far. While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*

Balthazar: Fine, if it'll spare me your bleating. The relic lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.

Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.

Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell... ...and he will come. My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar. See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy. Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace. Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver. Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours. Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Secrecy.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly. It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Shadowheart: A stinging truth - but a truth nonetheless.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being? If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain... We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The sisters aren't ready. They'll make me sick instead of curing me.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede. How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Practice - that's how I got good with a blade. They should spar each other. Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure? The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey. Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.

Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart. You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure. Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be. Observe - then succeed me, into the succour of Shar.

Wyll: Zevlor.
Zevlor: By Dhelt's virtue, the Blade of Frontiers? What's happened, Wyll?
Wyll: I paid the price of angering the wrong devil.
Zevlor: Believe me - I understand better than most.
Narrator: *A moment passes as Zevlor contemplates Wyll's words. He then turns his attentions to you.*
Zevlor: Have you spoken to Kagha?
Player: I want to discuss something else.
Zevlor: What is it?
Player: I'm looking for a man named Zorru.
Zevlor: You'll find him in camp. What do you want with him?
Player: That is between the two of us.
Zevlor: You'll find him in the caves. But I warn you not to start trouble. There's already enough going. Whatever your business here, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This latest attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Outsiders, perhaps. But not me.
Zevlor: Lucky you. There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: If your people survived that, they'll survive anything.
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.

Lae'zel: My queen.

Player: Kneel.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player kneels, head bowed, solemn, appropriate. Vlaakith offers something resembling a smile, and gestures for the player to rise. The player rises.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith looms in to face the player at their eye level.
Vlaakith: You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: Friend - I came to bring it back to you.
Wyll: Are you mad? That artefact's the only thing shielding us from the Absolute's voice.
Vlaakith: An unexpected servant. Your will is strong. Your kind's stoic endurance will be a boon to our cause. Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning. The Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I shall cleanse it for you, my queen. Tell me how.
InternalNodeContext: He's not altogether sure why this task is falling to the player and not to him, but also doesn't want to challenge his queen's motivations.
Vlaakith: SILENCE, W'wargaz. There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight. They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire. As long as they live, the Prism is compromised. Find the one inside and kill them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed. You must accept. Refuse, and know my fury.
Player: So the dream visitor is inside the artefact... I can't kill them. They protect me from the Absolute.
Vlaakith: You are being LIED TO. I WILL BE OBEYED!
NodeContext: she loses herself a bit in rage here,
Player: No. In fact, maybe I'll free the one inside.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic. Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.
Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn. But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do... How is this possible...?
Player: I think this artefact has something to do with it.
Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world. You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know. I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them. Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected. I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help. I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from. That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: Tell me what you've learned about the tadpoles' origins.
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers. Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic. If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: Altered parasites? A cure at Moonrise Towers, maybe? Sounds like guesswork at best.
Halsin: I'm as certain as I can be. If you have a better alternative, I won't stop you. I can't stop you, in fact. Which brings me to my next problem... I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise. I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Look around you - there's no order anymore. Only chaos.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural. Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.
 Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut. They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: You are aware you're asking me to kill a drow?
Halsin: You drow relish turning on your own, if there's something to be gained. Don't pretend otherwise.
Player: Not all drow are as you say.
Halsin: Unfair of me, perhaps, but I've had few encounters with drow to make me think otherwise. Perhaps you can enlighten me.
Player: Having a shapeshifting bear-druid at my side might make things easier. Follow me, then. Your bear form may prove useful.
Halsin: Be warned - my presence could make things more difficult... I can only restrain my bear form so much. I won't be able to help but attack goblins. If I join you, we'll likely have to slaughter this entire place. You may want to use discretion when approaching the goblin leaders.
Player: Stay here.

Player: I'm glad you made it too, it's one hell of a curse.
Alfira: It wasn't the curse that did us in. We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Asharak was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right. Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: I'm so sorry.
Alfira: It just... it just never stops. Rolan, of all people, saved us. He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: You're lucky to be alive.
Alfira: I don't feel lucky. I feel... I feel like I'm at the end of my rope. How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: It helps to remember what is at stake - I fight for nature, for balance. I fight for life itself.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: You came. Such a shame.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I hope so. But it is a faint hope. Just like me. I can't leave, I can only suffer. But I'm supposed to do that in silence. Everyone here hates me for what I am. I'm the thing that kills you, and the only reason you're alive. Made by a promise, undone by the truth. A handshake, a hug, the first beat of a newborn's heart. I am Hope. What little is left of her. A GUTTERING CANDLE IN A UNIVERSE OF NIGHT
Karlach: Raphael's driven her mad. Poor soul.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm not much of a friend to anyone anymore. But I could use a friend myself. Do you want a friend to guide you through this madhouse? Shhhtttt, I hear the jailor, it hears me. It'll call Raphael. Make every question count. Make some of them count twice.
Lae'zel: You must ask of the Orphic Hammer. Without it, the prince remains forever out of reach of my hungry weapon.
: NodeContext: urgent hushing and frantically getting out all of her words as quickly as possible. She's hushing the player, even though she was the one speaking

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Caveat venditor. Big mistake coming here while Raphael holds all the cards in his claws. But big mistakes correct bigger mistakes. Like scribbling your signature in the first place. Silly little mouse. But, yes. Hope can help. Your contract is here, in this House - it's...
Narrator: *You hear a sound like the rattle of a chain, and an agonising scream in your head as Hope flickers from view momentarily.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Shhhhttttt... Quiet... There it goes... Everyone here is mad - even you, especially me - and that makes them dangerous. But it also makes them stupid. I'll make you seem as ruined as the rest of the people here. A simple glamour to make you a terrible wretch.
NodeContext: very enthusiastic, casting a spell to disguise the player
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Now whisper your questions, little wretch. But really quiet, and very clever. Concentrate.

Alfira: You don't know? Stars above... We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Ikaron was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.
 Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.

Player: I'll do everything in my power to save them - you have my most solemn vow.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar. See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy. Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace. Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver. Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours. Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Secrecy.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly. It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Shadowheart: A stinging truth - but a truth nonetheless.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being? If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure. We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede. How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other. Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure? The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey. Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart. You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure. Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I am not worthy! Please, show me how a master works - I would be honoured. I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be. Observe - then succeed me, into the succour of Shar.

Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased. I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it? But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Nere mentioned that you were seeking access to the Temple. Looks like you found it.
Balthazar: Perhaps you'd be more useful dead than alive if you don't even know what I'm seeking here. But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Z'rell said Ketheric wants you to find a relic. That's all I know. As you mention serving Ketheric, he sent you to find a relic, no?
Balthazar: General Thorm to you. But yes, recovering the relic is the crux of it. He commands, and I, his humble servant, fulfil that command. While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him might just be the best way to gain access to Moonrise Towers.* *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: Jobs like this always go smoother when I know exactly what I'm looking for. I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?
Balthazar: Telling you will not make the task any less perilous. Just obey, and use your ignorance as a shield. You should be adept at that already. The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work... Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you. The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes. I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: For jobs like this it's good form to provide your operatives some extra resources.
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell... ...and he will come. My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
