Narrator: *The blessing falls uneasily over your tainted body. You can't help but dream: to kill her would destroy all of Last Light. You yearn for it so deeply...*
Shadowheart: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Perfect. It'll make you immune to the lesser effects of the shadow curse, which will get you closer to the Towers. It won't be enough to protect you against areas of utter darkness, though - where the curse is strongest. This lantern should, though.
Player: I already have a Moonlantern. I can safely travel the shadows.
Isobel: Well! If I'd have realised, I'd have spared the theatrics. In that case, you should be able to navigate a path straight to your target. That's good - very good. I wish you luck. The very best of it.

Alfira: First cultists nearly murder us, and now we have a traitor on the inside? Can't we trust anyone?
NodeContext: frustrated and tired of being scared
Player: Cultists? What happened?
Alfira: Stars, you hadn't heard?
 We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them. They lined us up like dogs. Ikaron was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.
 Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel... They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Which one was Asharak again?
Alfira: Which...? Back in the grove, he ran drills with the kids. Wooden swords and the like. That seems like a lifetime ago now. Rolan, of all people, saved us. He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: If he hadn't listened to me, maybe his brother and sister would still be here.
Alfira: Don't say that. When I think of what would have happened if Cal and Lia weren't there... How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: Danger is my life - I wouldn't change it for the world.

Abdirak: Greetings, child. I've met few aside from goblins here.
NodeContext: Player is one of the few non-goblins he's met in this place. Welcomes another for conversation and discussion but there should be something vaguely threatening about him. Charismatic, sexy, and creepy all in one.

Narrator: *You recognise the scourge - this man is a follower of Loviatar, goddess of pain.*
Abdirak: Ah, are you also here to assist with the prisoner?
Player: What prisoner?
Abdirak: The gentleman being held next door. My acquaintance is working on him, I believe. While I was thrilled to be invited here, I must confess I find the goblins and their methods... crude and primitive. Pain without purpose is a terrible thing, wouldn't you agree?
Player: Who invited you? A goblin?
Abdirak: Yes. He's just over there. Between you and I, his claims of mastery over pain are unfounded.
NodeContext: Player has asked who invited him here. It was a goblin who is torturing someone next door. His tone is dismissive. He believes the goblin doesn't know what he's doing.
Abdirak: Pain should be intimate and loving - not violent and brutish. Alas, he... Forgive me, but that look in your eyes - something terrible has happened to you.
Player: Clever man. How did you know?
Abdirak: Because I see those same eyes when I look in the mirror, dear one. We've all suffered in these dark times. It is little wonder you bear scars of pain and anguish. Please let me alleviate this pain.
Player: And how would you do that?
Abdirak: As the Maiden of Pain, the goddess Loviatar, teaches us... ...through penance - administered by my skilled hand. My work can grant peace and serenity - the likes of which few experience. It will be worth it - I promise.

thinks he's helping you.
thinks he's helping you.

Zevlor: The Blade of Frontiers. An honour, no matter the circumstance. I'd advise you to settle your affairs here quickly. Once the druids complete their ritual, we'll be sharing the road with goblins once again. Unless you've reconsidered speaking to them for us? Kagha might listen to you.
Player: I want to discuss something else.
Zevlor: What is it?
Player: I'm looking for a man named Zorru.
Zevlor: You'll find him in camp. What do you want with him?
Player: That is between the two of us.
Zevlor: You'll find him in the caves. But I warn you not to start trouble. There's already enough going. Whatever your business here, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out. This latest attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Outsiders, perhaps. But not me.
Zevlor: Lucky you. There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore. They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after goblins and gnolls attacked us on the road. We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Karlach: Gods, these are those tiefs? Their whole city was dragged into Avernus for a while. Zariel was delighted. When they made it back out, I'd hoped they got their happy ending.
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: If your people survived that, they'll survive anything.
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again. We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.

Player: So you killed them?
Ptaris: It is not my fault they died. I was only upholding father's code. Even he was not strong enough to follow it. He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure. Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death. Tell me - are you a good person?

Ptaris: There is no 'try'. You are either good or you are not. The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?
Player: I follow my gut. That's all anyone can do.
Ptaris: Your gut cannot be trusted. That is why the code exists. That is why you failed. I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head. You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.

Viconia DeVir: I thought you might try to flee, rather than face us. Perhaps you are braver than I thought - or more arrogant than even I can fathom. Now, do not be so foolish as to attack me. Unlike before, I am flesh and blood - but am very well protected.
Jaheira: You've finally found yourself a following, Mother Superior. And you only had to hollow out their heads to do it.

Viconia DeVir: Always a pleasure to see old acquaintances. But you would be wise to not interfere in this matter. No matter. You are here now, to face the Dark Lady's judgement, before a gathering of your peers. Give the artefact, and perhaps we will be merciful.
Shadowheart: No. I already faced Lady Shar. I passed her trials, I wielded her spear, and now I am her mortal voice. I have been embraced by her in ways you could only dream of.
Viconia DeVir: Nonsense. Ravings. You've strayed, girl - you've failed Lady Shar's mission and allowed ambition to rot your mind.
Shadowheart: Tell her. Tell them all. Tell them how the Nightsinger has blessed me.
Player: She slew a helpless prisoner, deep in an ancient ruin. Perhaps that warrants Shar's blessing.

Shadowheart: I'm not here to convince you, Mother. You are already disgraced in Lady Shar's eyes. I merely wish to give the others a chance to repent, before they are dragged down with you. Viconia would have you hide down here, oblivious to the true danger - the Absolute must be stopped, and only I can lead you. Lady Shar has decreed it!
Viconia DeVir: The Absolute will be dealt with. As soon as I prise the artefact from your cold fingers. Enough talk, girl. The sooner we finish this, the sooner your blood can be sluiced off Lady Shar's sacred Grotto.

Shadowheart: Enough speeches - the odds are already in my favour. Do you think the Dark Lady would want you to die for a lost cause? Or show some cunning and live another day?

Halsin: Nature's blessings. Are you ready to do what is necessary?
Player: Tell me what you know about Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Travelling to Moonrise is no small task. Expect dangers like you've never seen before.
Player: I'm something of an expert when it comes to imperilling myself.
Halsin: This is different. There's more fingers on a hand than there are survivors of that place.
Player: I think you're exaggerating. You just want me to stay and help you.
Halsin: I do want you to help me, yes. But I am not exaggerating. To get to the Towers, you'll need to pass through a terrible place - a cursed place. This curse shrouds everything in shadow - you will not find life, light, or anything natural there. Any who linger are twisted by the curse; they become shadow beings - tormented, dangerous souls.
Player: What do you suggest?
Halsin: You could go overland - along the Risen Road or through the mountains. Easier at first, but you'll run into the shadow curse eventually. You could also go under. There is a tunnel somewhere in this very temple of Selûne. It leads to Moonrise Towers through the Underdark. Long ago, a man called Ketheric Thorm built a secret stronghold deep down there, before rallying a whole army of Dark Justiciars - Shar worshippers.
Shadowheart: Dark Justiciars? I must see for myself.
Halsin: Aradin and his lot were looking for a way down there - they were promised riches if they retrieved a relic called the Nightsong. But I think there's more. From this stronghold, Ketheric's forces could access both the temple of Selûne and Moonrise Towers - but he was defeated before he could launch an attack. If you can find this place, I'll wager it will reveal a more direct path to Moonrise Towers, and may bypass the worst of the shadow curse.
Player: The Underdark's my home. Better to take that route than risk this curse.
Halsin: Anything is preferable to risking the shadow curse. You may reconsider once you see the effects of the curse for yourself.
Player: I may live to regret this - or maybe I won't - but fine, I'll help you save the grove first.
Halsin: You will? Oak Father bless you. I'll be in your debt twice over if we succeed. You know what's needed - the deaths of Dror Ragzlin, the drow Minthara, and the priestess, Gut. May nature guide you. I could come and help you... but be warned - I won't be able to suppress my animal side. Subtlety will not be an option. If I join you, we'll likely have to slaughter this entire place. You may want to use discretion when approaching the goblin leaders.
Player: Stay here.

Kith'rak Voss: Now, now, child - your pet means to speak. Tell me, pet: why shouldn't I run you through this instant? And as for you, tell me - why shouldn't I run you through this instant?
Player: I don't know you. I pose no threat.

Player: Lae'zel - stop. Before you do something you'll regret.

Narrator: *You recognise this as a trial, where initiates would prove themselves to Lady Shar. This one would challenge their combat prowess.*
InternalNodeContext: SH-only narration
Shadowheart: This is one of Lady Shar's trials. Allow me - please.
Player: No, keep back.
Shadowheart: Try it for yourself then - perhaps I'll learn from your death.
Player: Go on then - you do it. Go ahead.

Shadowheart: Everyone seems to be in high spirits.
NodeContext: Shadowheart and the player standing throughout this dialogue, chatting in a party setting. Shadowheart has a glass of wine in hand,
Shadowheart: I saw you with Lae'zel. You two looked... cosy. Far be it from me to judge. Blood must still be running a little hot after everything. Strange... you know who I never thought I'd find myself caring for?
Player: Me?
Shadowheart: Your words, not mine. But not what I mean. I mean desperate people... like those refugees. Never gave them much thought. Certainly not that bunch in the grove. Yet we came through for them. We saved their lives. Odd.
Player: Are you worried Shar won't approve?
Shadowheart: Something like that. I was taught to reject anything that distracted from Shar... ...but there'll be time for penance later. Share a bottle with me?
Player: I'd be glad to.
Shadowheart: I won't keep you long - I gather you've already made plans with someone for your evening.
NodeContext: The player's already spoken for and SH will respect that. Places her glass down to top it up, reaching for a nearby wine bottle.
Player: Maybe those plans could change, for the right person...
Narrator: *Shadowheart says nothing, but the glimmer of interest in her eyes is unmistakable.*
Player: I'll find you later, once the camp's asleep.

Shadowheart: This must be the last step. I need to pray. Only by Lady Shar's grace did we even make it this far.
Player: Lady... Shar? You worship her...?
Shadowheart: I do. I'm amazed you missed the signs, honestly. Now let me pray. This is important.
Player: Use the power of the parasite. Feel inside Shadowheart's mind.
Narrator: *You feel your mind slip into Shadowheart's - but you are not the only one present. There is another - ancient, commanding, rendered from purest darkness. Shar.*
Shar: ...Find my spear, step forward, and strike down the Selûnite.
Shadowheart: As you command, Nightsinger.
Shar: Now go. Warm my blade with moon-crazed blood. And be wary of your companion - they pry in your thoughts.
Shadowheart: That wasn't for you to hear.
Player: I deserve to know what I'm getting myself into.
Shadowheart: It's simple - I have a mission. It need not concern you - and as long as you don't interfere, it'll bring you no harm. When the time comes for me to do my duty, stand aside.
Player: All right. Fine. Let's move on.
Shadowheart: No. Not yet. We can't go on - not without the Spear of Night. We must return to the library.
Player: Back to the library it is. Fine - we'll go look for the spear first.
Shadowheart: Good. Somewhere in the library there should be an image of my Lady that we can shroud in darkness. The spear should reveal itself.

Raphael: There. Middle-of-somewhere.
Karlach: I don't like this at all.
Player: Nice decor.
Raphael: The House of Hope. Where the tired come to rest, and the famished come to feed - lavishly.
NodeContext: He spreads his arms as he dramatically introduces this place.
Raphael: Go on. Partake. Enjoy your supper. After all... ...it might just be your last.
Player: Ignore him and fill your plate.
Raphael: Not easily rattled, I see. Good. Makes the next part that much more straightforward. What's better than a devil you don't know? A devil you do.
Karlach: Fuck. A cambion.
Raphael: And so much more. Am I a friend? Potentially. An adversary? Conceivably. But a saviour? That's for certain.
Player: What makes you think I need saving?
Raphael: Come now. Why play hard to get when you're in deep over your tadpoled head? One skull, two tenants, and no solution in sight. I could fix it all like that.
NodeContext: He snaps his fingers on the word 'that'. As he does so, the candle flames suddenly shine unnaturally bright, bathing the scene in a hellish red glow.
Player: You're mad if you think I'll make a deal with a devil.

Shadowheart: Everyone seems to be in high spirits.
NodeContext: Shadowheart and the player standing throughout this dialogue, chatting in a party setting. Shadowheart has a glass of wine in hand,

Shadowheart: Something like that. I was taught to reject anything that distracted from Shar... ...but there'll be time for penance later. Share a bottle with me?
Player: Just a bottle?
Shadowheart: It's quite a bottle. I liberated one of the finer vintages earlier. Best enjoyed someplace private, I think.
Player: I'd be glad to.
Shadowheart: We should wait a little while. Until the others have drifted off.
Player: I'll find you after everyone's turned in for the night.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Wait! Argh. Wait just a tick. Killing me is a waste of time - I'll find a way to return. Always have, always will. But it's... unpleasant. So how about we be civilised about this, hmm? I have something you want.
Player: A servant of Vlaakith wants for nothing that her queen can't give.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Hold your horses - just hear me out. I can give you power. Anything you want! You want to be stronger? Tougher? Smarter? Done! Just let me go. (Ability Score +1)
Wyll: End her now, or she'll be cursing new victims by sundown.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: What'll it be, petal?
Player: You're a vile, monstrous creature. There is no bargain for you but death.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Tch. Doesn't it ever get lonely? Up on that high horse of yours? But have it your way. Tell your precious little god I say hello... after I rip out your throat!

Shadowheart: I can still feel the Shadowfell all over me... still hear her words in my ear. I feel... unclean.
Player: You mean Shar? Forget it - her spite can't hurt you now.
Shadowheart: I hope that's true, but I'm not so sure. She has a far reach, and a long memory. I have an idea. Something I've wanted to do for a while. Something that might help me put her in the past... but I'll need your help. I have an idea, but I'll need your help.
Player: What do I need to do?
Shadowheart: Just wait until the others are asleep, then come with me. There's a place we can go, down the coast a little.
Player: But what then? Come on, let's not start keeping secrets again.
Shadowheart: Do you remember what I told you before, about how I can't swim? Well, I think it's time I remedied that. And washed off Shar's bile at the same time. I need to take back control. Seize what I've been denied.
Player: If that's what you want, I'll be ready.
Shadowheart: Good. Until then. Get some rest while you can.

Lae'zel: You carry a githyanki relic. I will have an explanation - or your head.
NodeContext: Lae'zel and Shadowheart are having an argument. Both are standing.

Player: What's going on? Why're you two arguing?
Shadowheart: Lae'zel thinks I have something important to her people. She's deluded, clearly.
DIR: Try a take where SH spits out the clearly under her breath as an after thought

Player: So. Any ideas on how we settle this?
Lae'zel: The bad blood must be purged. A duel, come first light.
Shadowheart: You mean I'd get to prove you wrong and thrash you? I love it. Get some rest, Lae'zel - you'll need it.

Player: Actually, I've changed my mind. A devil such as Raphael can't truly be trusted.

Viconia DeVir: They already heard how you disgraced yourself before Lady Shar. How she marked you as the enemy. But it is quite another thing for them to see it for themselves. I am very glad you decided to return. A cautionary tale such as yours will be studied by Lady Shar's initiates for years to come. Always a pleasure to see old acquaintances. But you would be wise to not interfere in this matter. No matter. You are here now, to face the Dark Lady's judgement, before a gathering of your peers. Give the artefact, and perhaps we will be merciful.
Shadowheart: No. I already faced Lady Shar. I passed her trials, I wielded her spear, and now I am her mortal voice. I have been embraced by her in ways you could only dream of.
Viconia DeVir: Nonsense. Ravings. You've strayed, girl - you've failed Lady Shar's mission and allowed ambition to rot your mind.
Shadowheart: Tell her. Tell them all. Tell them how the Nightsinger has blessed me.
Player: Wait. Before we go any further, tell me what this is about. Why do you even want the artefact?
Viconia DeVir: I did not consent to questions. But I suppose you have undergone a great deal to reach this place, and anything I tell you cannot compromise me now - for you will either leave on my terms, or not at all... Whispers reached my ears from all corners - potential rivals of Lady Shar, all vying for the same prize. A new god, amassing the disaffected, the outcasts - those who should turn to us. This 'Absolute' is but an upstart; disturbing the natural order and threatening to impede the glorious return of Lady Shar's pure, endless darkness. I had to act. I had to strangle that foul conspiracy while it was still in the cradle. We learned all we could - the artefact was the one thing the Absolutists feared. The one thing they desperately wanted to keep out of their enemies' grasp. I had to have it.
Player: I've heard enough.
Shadowheart: Tell them what you witnessed. Tell them how Lady Shar favours me. Tell her. Tell them all. Tell them how the Nightsinger has blessed me.
Player: Wait. Before we go any further, tell me what this is about. Why do you even want the artefact?
Viconia DeVir: I did not consent to questions. But I suppose you have undergone a great deal to reach this place, and anything I tell you cannot compromise me now - for you will either leave on my terms, or not at all... Whispers reached my ears from all corners - potential rivals of Lady Shar, all vying for the same prize. A new god, amassing the disaffected, the outcasts - those who should turn to us. This 'Absolute' is but an upstart; disturbing the natural order and threatening to impede the glorious return of Lady Shar's pure, endless darkness. I had to act. I had to strangle that foul conspiracy while it was still in the cradle. We learned all we could - the artefact was the one thing the Absolutists feared. The one thing they desperately wanted to keep out of their enemies' grasp. I had to have it.
Player: I've heard enough.
Shadowheart: Tell them what you witnessed. Tell them how Lady Shar favours me. Tell her. Tell them all. Tell them how the Nightsinger has blessed me.
Player: It's true. She survived the Gauntlet of Shar. She sacrificed Selûne's own daughter. She is your rightful leader.
Justiciar Crusader Nightmist: A true Sharran like you must be on the right side.
NodeContext: Supportive, swayed by the player's argument
Justiciar Crusader Nightmist: I shall stand with Shadowheart.
NodeContext: Swearing fealty (having just changed sides to support the player)

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Wait! Argh. Wait just a tick. Killing me is a waste of time - I'll find a way to return. Always have, always will. But it's... unpleasant. So how about we be civilised about this, hmm? I have something you want.
Player: What I want is Mayrina - alive and free.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: But she's worthless to you! Let me leave with the girl, and I'll give you power. You want to be stronger? Tougher? Smarter? Done! Anything is possible. (Ability Score +1) Just let me keep the girl and her babe.
Lae'zel: A simple trade? More deception. Take her head.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: It's your choice, sweetness.
Player: Hags are the scourge of the natural world. I'm going to kill you - as many times as needed.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: I've never been called a scourge before, you flirt. But sweet words won't get you out of this one!

Shadowheart: This must be the last step. I need to pray. Only by Lady Shar's grace did we even make it this far.

Narrator: *You feel her mind flare in anger - she's sensed your intrusion.*
Shadowheart: Can't I even pray without interference?
NodeContext: Furious
Player: I'm sorry, I couldn't help myself.
Shadowheart: Yes, you could have. Don't pretend otherwise. There's something I need to do once we enter the Dark Lady's domain. Any more meddling on your part will end badly.
Player: Whatever you think you're going to do in there - forget it. Forget it. We're not going to sacrifice a life to Shar.
Shadowheart: You will not stand in my way. Draw your weapon.
Player: All right. Fine. Let's move on.

Shadowheart: Everyone seems to be in high spirits.
NodeContext: Shadowheart and the player standing throughout this dialogue, chatting in a party setting. Shadowheart has a glass of wine in hand,
Shadowheart: I saw you with Wyll. You two looked... cosy. Far be it from me to judge. Blood must still be running a little hot after everything. Strange... you know who I never thought I'd find myself caring for?
Player: Shar?
Shadowheart: What? No, don't be ridiculous. I mean desperate people... like those refugees. Never gave them much thought. Certainly not that bunch in the grove. Yet we came through for them. We saved their lives. Odd.
Player: Are you worried Shar won't approve?
Shadowheart: Something like that. I was taught to reject anything that distracted from Shar... ...but there'll be time for penance later. Share a bottle with me?
Player: I'd be glad to.
Shadowheart: We should wait a little while. Until the others have drifted off.
Player: I'll find you after everyone's turned in for the night.

Shadowheart: Bloody hells - literally. Just when I think I've got a grasp on our dilemma, a devil shows up... No matter. We've dealt with every other oddity thrown at us lately - we can handle this one too. Now, as for this 'Raphael'... He knows our secret, he claims he can help... what do you make of him?
Player: Help is help, no matter the source.
Shadowheart: Oh you were tempted, were you? Interesting. What grabbed you, exactly? His parlour tricks? His manners? The lavish spread, even? You must have found something alluring, to overlook the fact he was a devil.
Player: Use your shared connection to hear her thoughts.

Shadowheart: As you command, Nightsinger.
Shar: Now go. Warm my blade with moon-crazed blood. And be wary of your companion - they pry in your thoughts.

Player: I deserve to know what I'm getting myself into.
Shadowheart: It's simple - I have a mission. It need not concern you - and as long as you don't interfere, it'll bring you no harm. When the time comes for me to do my duty, stand aside.
Player: All right. Fine. Let's move on.
Shadowheart: No. Not yet. We can't go on - not without the Spear of Night. We must return to the library.
Player: I don't care about the spear - I'm continuing.
Shadowheart: My Lady does not want you to. Please. Don't make me do this - not after all we've been through.
NodeContext: Imploring someone she respects to change their mind, or she'll be forced to attack them
Player: Fine - we'll go look for the spear first.
Shadowheart: Good. Somewhere in the library there should be an image of my Lady that we can shroud in darkness. The spear should reveal itself.

Shadowheart: I saw you with Karlach. You two looked... cosy. Far be it from me to judge. Blood must still be running a little hot after everything. Strange... you know who I never thought I'd find myself caring for?
Player: Refugees?
Shadowheart: Exactly right. Never gave them much thought. Certainly not that bunch in the grove. I mean desperate people... like those refugees. Never gave them much thought. Certainly not that bunch in the grove. Yet we came through for them. We saved their lives. Odd.
Player: Not so odd. We did the right thing.
Shadowheart: That's more easily said by some than others. But nobody's here to debate right from wrong. Share a bottle with me?
Player: Just a bottle?
Shadowheart: Just a bottle. I think you have other plans afterwards - wouldn't want to keep you. ...Well, maybe I would. But first come, first served.
Player: Maybe those plans could change, for the right person...
Narrator: *Shadowheart says nothing, but the glimmer of interest in her eyes is unmistakable.*
Player: I'll find you later, once the camp's asleep.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Wait! Argh. Wait just a tick. Killing me is a waste of time - I'll find a way to return. Always have, always will. But it's... unpleasant. So how about we be civilised about this, hmm? I have something you want.
Player: What I want is Mayrina - alive and free.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: But she's worthless to you!
Mayrina: Don't let her take me. Please.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Shut it. You owe me a babe, girl. And I'll take it - whether you like it or not. Let me leave with the girl, and I'll give you power. You want to be stronger? Tougher? Smarter? Done! Anything is possible. (Ability Score +1) Just let me keep the girl and her babe.
Gale: Not only would this be a vile deal, it would be folly to trust a hag's gifts.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: It's your choice, sweetness.
Player: I know a beaten opponent when I see one. Give me the power and the girl, and I'll let you live.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: You greedy little bollocks! Fine. Here.

Shadowheart: Wait until the others are asleep, then come with me. There's a place we can go, down the coast a little.

Viconia DeVir: I thought you might try to flee, rather than face us. Perhaps you are braver than I thought - or more arrogant than even I can fathom. Now, do not be so foolish as to attack me. Unlike before, I am flesh and blood - but am very well protected.
Jaheira: You've finally found yourself a following, Mother Superior. And you only had to hollow out their heads to do it.
Minsc: Pin your eyes to the treacherous she-drow. Do not focus on the many, many others - Boo will handle them.
Viconia DeVir: Always a pleasure to see old acquaintances. But you would be wise to not interfere in this matter. No matter. You are here now, to face the Dark Lady's judgement, before a gathering of your peers. Give the artefact, and perhaps we will be merciful.
Shadowheart: No. I already faced Lady Shar. I passed her trials, I wielded her spear, and now I am her mortal voice. I have been embraced by her in ways you could only dream of.
Viconia DeVir: Nonsense. Ravings. You've strayed, girl - you've failed Lady Shar's mission and allowed ambition to rot your mind.
Shadowheart: Tell her. Tell them all. Tell them how the Nightsinger has blessed me.
Player: Wait. Before we go any further, tell me what this is about. Why do you even want the artefact?
Viconia DeVir: I did not consent to questions. But I suppose you have undergone a great deal to reach this place, and anything I tell you cannot compromise me now - for you will either leave on my terms, or not at all... Whispers reached my ears from all corners - potential rivals of Lady Shar, all vying for the same prize. A new god, amassing the disaffected, the outcasts - those who should turn to us. This 'Absolute' is but an upstart; disturbing the natural order and threatening to impede the glorious return of Lady Shar's pure, endless darkness. I had to act. I had to strangle that foul conspiracy while it was still in the cradle. We learned all we could - the artefact was the one thing the Absolutists feared. The one thing they desperately wanted to keep out of their enemies' grasp. I had to have it.
Player: Shar bid you to do all of this?
Viconia DeVir: Lady Shar's concerns lie elsewhere - with another. But she is a goddess... she can afford to ignore that which does not threaten her. I must keep her faith alive in mortal hearts. I must defend her ways, lead her children, stop all threats. Even if I must go against her wishes, I will prove myself her most loyal servant.
Shadowheart: You think you know better than the Dark Lady? No wonder she sent me to this place of your poison. Tell them what you witnessed. Tell them how Lady Shar favours me. Tell her. Tell them all. Tell them how the Nightsinger has blessed me.
Player: I saw her walk through a shadow curse, where others feared to venture. Shar favours her.
Justiciar Crusader Nightmist: A true Sharran like you must be on the right side.
NodeContext: Supportive, swayed by the player's argument
Justiciar Crusader Nightmist: I shall stand with Shadowheart.
NodeContext: Swearing fealty (having just changed sides to support the player)

Shadowheart: Good. Until then. Get some rest while you can.

Shadowheart: What do you know about me? You spoke of my past, being chased by wolves - I told no one about that... ...Almost no one. But I certainly didn't share that with you.
Nightsong: There is nothing I can tell you that you do not already know yourself. They trained you well, trained you hard. Chiselled away any part of you that did not fit their plan. They made you forget.
Shadowheart: I chose to do that. For the mission. To protect Shar's -
Nightsong: - secrets. Yes, yes. That is an old song, girl. Your goddess cares more for her precious secrets than she does her devotees.
Shadowheart: Get to the point.
Nightsong: When you freed me, you severed a bond between me and that dog, Thorm. A bond of pain - his, inflicted on me. When I laid eyes on you, I sensed a similar bond. You, tethered to two others, someplace distant. Let me help you remember.
Narrator: *You feel Shadowheart's mind tug at the edges of your own. You know this sensation. She wants you to see whatever is about to be revealed.*
Player: Open your mind to that sensation.
Narrator: *Your mind joins with Shadowheart's. Something pulls at you both, bringing you elsewhere...* *Something sparks in your memory. Teachings about Selûnite rites of passage, about how they would abandon their children out in the wilds and force them to find their way home...* *...It seems that one child never came back. She was taken.*
Shadowheart: What... who was that man?
Nightsong: You already know. Did you not see yourself in him? Do you not recognise your own blood?
Shadowheart: My father? That was him?

I've dreamed of this place. This is my destiny - I must complete the trials.
Player: All right, I'll help if I can.

Shadowheart: It all stems from that childhood memory I suppose... it's strange. I know now that it was my father I saw, yet still, I can't suppress the fear. I suppose fear doesn't have to be rational. But maybe, given time, I can put it behind me.
Player: I'll try to avoid wolves in future, where possible.
Shadowheart: You will? Well... thank you. I appreciate it.

Shadowheart: Bloody hells - literally. Just when I think I've got a grasp on our dilemma, a devil shows up... No matter. Player: Help is help, no matter the source.
